description: This model, the design for which was patented in 1842 by Mr. W. S. Henson, was built in 1844-5 by Messrs. Henson and J. Stringfellow. Henson's proposal to utilise the fixed surfaces of an aeroplane to obtain support from the air was regarded at the time as a possible solution of the problem of flight. Henson's idea was to imitate soaring birds, all previous attempts being based on vibrating or rotating surfaces, after the manner of flapping wings. It was intended that the actual machine should be used as a conveyer of letters, goods, and passengers. The model consists of an extended surface or aeroplane of oiled silk or canvas, stretched upon a bamboo frame made rigid by trussing, both above and below. A car is attached to the under side of the aeroplane to contain the steam engine, passengers, etc. It has three wheels to run freely upon when it reaches earth. Two propellers, 3 ft. diameter, are shown with their blades set at 45 degrees; they are operated by endless cords from the steam engine (see No. 40). Behind these is a fan-shaped tail, stretched upon a triangular frame capable of being opened out, closed, or moved up and down by means of cords and pulleys. By this latter arrangement ascent or descent was to be accomplished. A rudder for steering sideways is placed under the tail, and above the main aeroplane a sail (not shown) was to be stretched between two masts rising from the car, to assist in maintaining the course. When in motion the front edge of the machine was to be raised in order to obtain the required air support. To start the model it was proposed to allow it to run down an incline, e.g., the side of a hill, the propellers being first set in motion. The velocity gained in the descent was expected to sustain it in its further progress, the engine overcoming the head resistance when in full flight. Experiments were eventually made on the downs, near Chard, and the night trials were abandoned, as the silk became saturated from a deposit of dew. After many day trials, down wide, inclined rails, the model was found to be deficient in stable equilibrium for open-air experiments, little puffs of wind or ground currents being sufficient to destroy the balance. The actual machine was never constructed, but in 1847-48 J. Stringfellow built a model which is supposed to be the first flying machine which performed a successful flight. A lithograph of the proposed machine is shown.

description: The model of which the wings, tail, engine and boiler are shown was constructed by Mr. J. Stringfellow in 1846, and was designed for indoor experiments. The sustaining planes were shaped like the wings of a bird, and were slightly curved on the under side. They were also feathered at the back edge, in order that the yielding of the feathers might automatically regulate the fore-and-aft stability. It is stated that during the experiments the model rose after leaving the sustaining wire as much as 1 in 7, and that a free flight of about 40 yds. was eventually made with the model. The sustaining surface was 17 sq. ft., and the planes measured 10 ft. over the tips. The motive power was supplied by a steam engine placed inside a car between and underneath the wings. It had a cylinder .75 in. diameter by 2 in. stroke. The boiler was of the water-tube type as used by Henson, Stringfellow, and others, and consisted of inverted truncated cones arranged around and above the furnace. The cones were connected with a central steam drum above them and with water chambers below. Two four-bladed propellers 16 in. diameter were employed. The propeller speed was increased in the ratio of 3 : 1 by bevel gear on the crank shaft. The weight of the model, including the engine, was 6 lb., and with water and fuel, 6·5 lb. The engine and boiler, which have since been used to work a small lace machine, are not now in their correct relative position as used by Stringfellow.

description: This is a complete model of the flying machine constructed and experimentally tried by Sir Hiram Maxim in 1894; by its own effort it more than supported its weight and that of its crew. It never soared aloft, however, as its rise was limited to a few inches only, by inverted rails, and an accident when running under these at a speed of 40 miles per hour brought the experiments to a premature conclusion. The total weight of the machine was 7,700 lb., and it exerted in the trials a total lifting effort of 10,000 lb. The machine consists of a braced structure of steel tubes and wires connected to large inclined surfaces, called aeroplanes, that possess a total area of 5,400 sq. ft. and slope at an angle of 7·25 degrees with the horizontal. The extreme width of the machine is 120 ft. and the length 104 ft. It is propelled by two two-bladed screws, each 17·83 ft. diameter by 16 ft. pitch, driven by compound engines with cylinders 5 in. and 8 in. diameter by 12 in. stroke, making 375 revolutions per minute and exerting together 360 h.p. The thrust from the two propellers working in the air is 2,000 lb., and the lifting effort is derived from this by the action of the aeroplanes. Steam at 300 lb. pressure is supplied from a tubulous boiler of the Thornycroft type, fired by naphtha delivered under a pressure of 50 lb. as 7,650 spray jets through hollow firebars. The boiler has a heating surface of 800 sq. ft. and a grate area of 30 sq. ft.; its weight is 900 lb., and with feed heaters, burners and water 1,200 lb.

description: This machine is one of those used by Otto Lilienthal in his experiments on “gliding” near Berlin, in 1895 and 1896. Unfortunately, during one of these flights, in August, 1896, the machine then employed capsized and fell to the ground, Lilienthal being killed. The wings, which may be folded, are constructed of fabric mounted on willow ribs, the hinge centres of the wings being about 6 ft. apart. The wings are held in position by a number of supporting wires above and below, attached to king-posts. The principal member of the framework is an approximately circular hoop of willow, across which pass in a fore-and-aft direction two willow rods that ultimately converge at a point where the bamboo tail rod emerges from the wing surface. Transversely across the hoop passes the main beam, and immediately behind this an opening is provided in the surface to accommodate the upper part of the pilot’s body. Two small bolsters attached to the frame rest under the pilot’s shoulders, and the pilot’s arms pass through rests provided for them in the corners of the x-shaped main beam. The tail portion of the machine is supported by a bamboo rod, and consists of a horizontal plane hinged separately to a vertical plane which is attached rigidly to the main frame. The control of the machine is effected by the movement of the pilot’s body to correct any deviation from the level position.

description: The early investigations of Octave Chanute in America were on the subject of bird flight, and it was not until the year 1895 that he began the construction of a glider in collaboration with Herring, a pupil of Lilienthal. The Chanute glider was developed from a multiplane, with wing tips which swung back, when struck by wind gusts, into a simple and more efficient two-decker as shown, in which the tail was partly controlled by springs. The wings were single surfaced, with the ribs exposed. The pilot hung with his armpits supported by the padded rests on the framework of the machine, and controlled the balance by movements of his body. The example shown resembles generally one of the later forms of his glider, and is a biplane with considerable camber to the wings. Levers control the rudder and the elevator, but some of the details shown on the machine are modifications from the original design.

description: Presented by The Weiss Aeroplane and Launcher Syndicate, Ltd., London, E.C. 1912. This model glider is a development of one shown at Paris in 1905 by Mr. José Weiss, and patented by him in 1908 in Great Britain. It was designed with a view to obtain automatic stability. The glides were made from the top of a hill in a direction directly opposed to that of the wind, and it is stated that the gliding speed of the model in relation to the atmosphere was between 30 and 35 miles per hour. The glider is a monoplane constructed on the lines of the albatross, and the framework consists of bamboo, the joints being made with tire cement and tarred twine. The main wings possess, at the middle, considerable thickness, and taper towards the tips, where they are flexible and flat. They are characterised by a distinct change of angle of incidence from the fuselage to the tip. Near the body the angle is greatest and is about 5 degrees, and from here it gradually decreases towards the wing tip. The tips themselves are upturned in such a way that they present a marked negative angle of incidence. A tail is provided, and, in the model, which was launched by hand, a roll of lead formed the weight, which was slipped over a vertical rod at the junction of the main frame with the landing skids, in a position corresponding to the breast of a bird. It is claimed that the design of the glider gives it a large amount of automatic stability, both longitudinal and lateral, and much experimental work has been carried out near Arundel with this and subsequent man-carrying gliders. The power-driven machine constructed in 1910 on the lines of the model had a total sustaining surface of 185 sq. ft., with a span of 34 ft., and weighed, with the pilot, 750 lb. A notable feature of this machine was the absence of cross-bracing, the compression and tension members being both provided for by the bamboo triangulated framework. Lashings of tarred string were employed as on the gliders. The tail of the machine combined the functions both of elevator and rudder, and there was no control of the wings themselves in the hands of the pilot. An eight-cylinder E.N.V. engine of about 30 h.p. was fitted and drove a single tractor screw of 7 ft. diameter. Inv. 1912-102. S.M. 1402. L.S.

description: The early experiments of Messrs. Orville and Wilbur Wright, of Dayton, Ohio, were made with soaring machines, which were abandoned, however, in 1903 in favour of power-driven aeroplanes. In 1906 the brothers took out a U.S.A. patent, claiming the essential features of their improved machine. The model represents the biplane used by Mr. W. Wright on the racecourse of Hunaudières, near Le Mans, in the autumn of 1908. It consists of two horizontal superposed planes, nearly rectangular in plan, the greater length being in a direction at right angles to the line of flight. At the rear is a double vertical rudder for steering in a lateral direction, and in front of the main planes two smaller superposed horizontal planes serve to control the vertical flight path of the machine. These front and rear rudders are nearly balanced, so that they can be easily moved by the control levers. The small semi-circular plane between the elevators is connected with the rear rudders, and is designed to act exclusively as a tell-tale. The aeroplane is mounted upon two wooden runners or skids, which extend forward and form supports for the front rudder. The whole structure is braced with wooden struts and wire ropes, the vertical wooden struts between the main planes being spaced at about 6 ft. intervals. The planes are constructed of cotton fabric, stretched over ribbed frames; in the model the port sides of the planes and the port rudder are uncovered in order to show the construction of the framing. Two seats are shown, that on the left is for the aviator, the other one being for a passenger or pupil. Only two levers are used by Mr. Wilbur Wright, one on either side, the one on his left being duplicated on the right-hand side of the passenger. The left-hand lever controls the front rudder only, whilst the other one has two controls. A fore-and-aft motion operates the rear rudder, and a motion sideways operates the plane-warping mechanism of the machine. Side balance is maintained through the warping of the wings; moreover, it is stated that the vertical rudder is never used alone in changing the direction of the machine.

description: The earliest experiments of Mons. L. Blériot were made in 1901 with a flapping- wing machine which failed. His first successful flight was accomplished in July, 1907, when the monoplane principle was adopted, and the steady development of this type of machine has resulted in the successful form shown by the model, the most notable achievements of which were a cross-country flight of 25 miles, and the crossing of the English Channel from Calais to Dover on July 25th, 1909. The model shown represents the machine known as No. XI, with which the Channel crossing was made. It is of the single passenger type, and, with the exception of the monoplane of M. Santos-Dumont (see No. 11), is the smallest which has met with any success.

description: Scale 1: 10. Made in the Museum, 1910. As the lightest practical machine that has successfully flown the “Demoiselle” represented by the model is of considerable interest. With it M. Santos-Dumont rose from the ground in the record time of 6·2 secs., and attained the high speed of 60 miles per hour in free flight. fabric which encloses the spars and bamboo ribs is double, and is formed of silk. The leading and trailing edges of the planes are quite sharp, and are supported by wires held in claws at the ends of the bamboo ribs. The fabric envelops the wire at the leading edge, but at the trailing edge it is laced to the wire, thus ensuring that the wings are stretched tightly. The greatest camber of the planes is slightly in front of the centre and is approximately 4 in. The tail is built up of fabric stretched on a bamboo frame, and moves as a whole about a universal joint formed at the after end of the chassis. The lever on the right hand of the aviator elevates or depresses the tail, while the steering wheel moves it sideways, both the motions being controlled by steel wires kept taut by springs. The lever at the back of the aviator controls the warping or flexing of the wings; it is attached at its upper end to his coat, so that by leaning over sideways in either direction the wings are warped as required. The aviator sits beneath the engine, on a strip of canvas stretched between the two lower bamboos of the main frame. The engine represented is a twin-cylinder Darracq motor of 25-30 h.p. The cylinders are placed horizontally on opposite sides of the crank-case, and are 130 mm. (5·12 in.) diam. by 120 mm. (4·72 in.) stroke. The engine is coupled directly to the propeller, which acts as a flywheel. Water-cooling is employed, and the radiator, consisting of numerous small copper pipes, is placed beneath the main plane on each side. The water enters the tubes from the cylinders at the top, and after traversing them is pumped back again. The weight of the engine is taken at the centre by the central bamboo, and at the cylinder ends by the transverse spars of the main planes, which are themselves supported at these points by oval steel struts connected with the chassis. In addition, two tie rods connect the engine at the rear with the top bamboo of the main frame. The petrol tank is placed above the motor, and is shown on the model, but the water tank, which is also placed above the motor, is not represented. The propeller, 6·66 ft. diameter, is of the Chauvière type built up in walnut, and makes 1,500 revolutions per minute. description: (Scale 1:10.) Messrs. Philipp Spandow, Ltd. 1913. The type of monoplane represented, which, in Germany, is known by the name of “Rumpler” or “Rumpler-Taube,” and in Austria by the name of “Etrich,” was designed by Etrich and Wels in 1908. The machine then built, named the “Etrich Wels III,” was very similar to the modern Etrich monoplane, so successful in Austria, excepting that it had a front elevating plane that has since been removed. Both in Austria and in Germany this type of monoplane is greatly relied upon for military purposes, and many fine flights stand to its credit in both countries. With a Rumpler monoplane Hirth won the first German reliability competition, and in 1911 flew from Munich to Berlin with the same type of machine. The entire construction is on similar lines to those adopted by Lilienthal in his glider, and, on account of the general resemblance of the machine to a bird it was often called “Taube” or “pigeon.” The main frame of the machine consists of a central fuselage built of wood and entirely enclosed. It is of trapezoidal section at the front, where it affords accommodation for seats for the pilot and passenger tandem fashion. At the rear of the frame the transverse section changes into a triangular one. The supporting planes are shaped like a bird's wings, and the entire rear edge is flexible. The trailing edges of each plane or wings are curved upward at the tips, and this construction is stated to give great automatic stability. The two wings are set at a small dihedral angle. The main bracing of the wings consists of a single girder built of wood, placed laterally under the planes. The latter are braced by a large number of stay wires, both above and below, and the method followed is similar to that adopted by Lilienthal. The tail of the machine, which resembles that of a bird, extends from the after end of the fuselage, and consists of a horizontal and two vertical surfaces. The control for the horizontal portion of the tail, i.e. the elevator, is by means of a column or vertical lever pivoted at its base to move backward and forward. A forward push away from the pilot turns the tail down and elevates the machine. The rudder consists of two triangular surfaces, one above and one below the elevator, and is operated by pedals. Warping of the wings is accomplished by wire and pulley connections to a steering wheel mounted on the control column. The landing chassis is of the Blériot type, and consists of two bicycle wheels at the front of the machine, together with a rear skid. The wheels, except in the military type, can be steered while the running over the ground. Power is supplied by a four-cylinder, water-cooled motor of 70 h.p., built in the front of the fuselage, the radiators being on each side of the latter. Inv. 1913-442. S.M. 353. L.S.

description: (Scale, 1: 10.) Made by Messrs. Philipp Spandow, Ltd. 1913 The model represents the Wright passenger biplane of 1911, which resembles closely the “Baby” Wright machine of 1910, designed especially for high speed. The machine differs in several essential points from the original Wright design, and a most noticeable departure consists in placing the monoplane elevator at the rear of the machine, where it forms part of the tail. The double elevator which was formerly at the front of the machine disappears entirely, and there are merely a pair of small surfaces, situated above and on the skids, fulfilling the same purpose as the half-moon shaped planes fitted between the front elevating planes in the earlier design. These surfaces tend to make the machine sensitive to movements of the rudder. The second important departure from the standard practice is the control, known as the Orville Wright control. The left-hand lever operates the simple elevator as previously, but it is fitted with a friction brake which automatically locks the lever in any desired position. The movements of the right-hand lever differ in their result entirely from those of the corresponding lever of the earlier design. A fore-and-aft movement of the lever warps the wing tips, and also moves the rudder, both these movements being obtained simultaneously. In addition to these movements the handle of the lever is hinged, and can be moved sideways by a wrist movement independently of the lever itself. The handle is connected by means of a bell-crank lever and rod with a free quadrant on the operating rock-shaft, the quadrant being connected with the rudder. description: Mr. S. Cody had gained considerable experience both with man-lifting kites and with the dirigible balloon "Nulli Secundus" before he designed his first aeroplane with which, in 1908, he made his first flight. The machine shown is his only biplane now remaining, and is the actual one which flew over Cambridge during the military manœuvres of September, 1912. It is practically identical in design with its predecessor, with which Mr. Cody won the military competition in the previous August. The aeroplane which was used by Mr. Cody when he met with a fatal accident in August, 1913, was similar in general features to these machines, but the divided elevator shown was replaced by a single elevator, and floats were substituted for the landing chassis in order to convert the machine into a hydro-aeroplane. One of the chief features of the machine shown is the divided front elevator, the two portions of which are capable of being warped in unison with the warping control of the main planes, as well as of being employed as an ordinary single elevator. The elevators are carried at their ends by long bamboo outriggers fastened to the ends of the struts between the main planes, and at the centre by outriggers carried to the landing chassis, and to the centre of the upper plane. There is no rear elevator. The tail, which is supported by long outriggers, consists of twin rudders, together with a pair of small fixed horizontal planes that serve as damper planes and help to preserve the longitudinal stability of the machine. Control is effected by means of a universally-pivoted rod with a hand-wheel top, the feet being entirely free. This rod is free to move either laterally or fore-andaft, as well as to rotate on its axis. The last-named movement is used to control the rudders; the fore-and-aft movement of the lever controls the elevators acting as one, whilst the lateral motion operates the warping mechanism, the rudders and the differential movement of the elevators. The steering wheel is used for separate rudder control when turning. Immediately behind the pilot's seat is a passenger seat, whilst two other passenger seats were sometimes placed behind the pilot, but outside the " nacelle." The landing chassis is of heavy construction, and consists of a long stout central skid carrying a small pair of wheels in front, together with a larger pair situated in front of and under the main planes. These wheels are mounted on vertical telescopic tubes with spring shock absorbers; the wheel track is 3.5 ft. gauge. Small wheels are fitted as fenders to the wing tips. In the construction of the machine silver spruce was used for the spars and struts, hickory for the landing chassis, and bamboo bound with tape for the outriggers. The motor, which was of the six-cylinder Austrian Daimler type of 120 h.p., was carried on bearers placed on a platform supported from the chassis by diagonal struts. It drove a propeller, of Mr. Cody's design, 10.5 ft. diameter, at a comparatively low speed through a twin roller chain reduction gear.

description: SHORT TWIN-ENGINE BIPLANE. (Scale about 1 : 12.) Lent by Lieut.-Colonel F. K. McClean, A.F.C., 1913. 1913 This is a model of the first practical twin-engine aeroplane, built by Messrs. Short Bros. in August, 1911. In general features the machine resembles the Farman biplane of 1910. There are two elevators, one at the front and the other at the rear of the machine. These are simultaneously operated by a pivoted column on which is mounted a wheel that operates the ailerons. Triple rudders are employed, and are controlled by a pedal of the usual Farman type. The landing chassis and all the details of construction have been specially strengthened owing to the extra weight carried. Power is provided by two 50 h.p. Gnome motors placed on the fore-and-aft centre line, and revolving in opposite directions. The front motor drives, by chain gearing, two tractor screws of high pitch, in a similar manner to that adopted on the Wright biplane. The rear motor drives a single propeller of low pitch at high speed, as on the Farman machine. Either motor may be operated separately. The difference in form between the slow-speed tractor screws and the high-speed propeller should be noted. The speed of this machine was said to range from 35 to 55 miles per hour, depending on whether one or both motors were used. Inv. 1913-447. S.M. 1489. L.S.

description: The biplane represented was built by Messrs. Short Bros. in 1911 as a land machine, and was used for military purposes. The landing chassis was replaced by floats in 1912, and the model represents the waterplane used by Colonel McClean in his flight up the Thames from the Isle of Sheppey to Westminster in August, 1912. The machine is of the military type, with wing extensions to the upper main planes supported by stays attached to the extremities of the lower planes, and in this and other respects the construction of the machine resembles that of the Farman biplane (see No. 9). The tail consists of a horizontal lifting plane with a hinged member forming part of the elevator, together with a divided rudder, half above and half below the horizontal plane. A front elevator is provided, and is operated in unison with the rear elevator by a vertical lever. From this lever wires also pass to the hinged flaps or “ ailerons ” controlling the lateral stability of the machine. The rudder is operated by a pedal as in the Farman biplane. Motive power was supplied by a 50 h.p. Gnome engine. The floats are shown constructed entirely of wood, but the actual floats were built up of double canvas tops and sides, the remaining parts being of three-ply wood on a frame of laths.

description: This model represents the military biplane of the 1913 type, designed by M. Henri Farman. It should be compared with the Farman biplane of 1911 (see No. 9), from which it was evolved. The brothers Maurice and Henri Farman combined in 1912 to manufacture aeroplanes in large quantities; they established a headquarters at Billancourt (Seine). The 1913 Henri Farman showed many improvements in design, the result of innumerable flights and experiments conducted with the object of producing a machine of greater speed and capable of quick manœuvre. An aluminium nacelle was fitted in the centre section of this machine. It contained seats for the pilot and observer; the latter occupied the rear seat, which was on a slightly higher level. The longerons, rudder post, and under-carriage were made of steel tubing, a departure from previous Farman practice. The forward elevator was abolished, a single rear plane and elevator being employed with a single rudder in place of that in duplicate on the earlier model. The modern type of spring tail skid was also fitted. A 70–80 h.p. Gnome engine was used with this as with the earlier machine.

description: This type of aeroplane which has been adopted as the standard training machine by the Royal Air Force, was originally designed in 1913 for an 80 h.p. Gnome engine, and was used successfully during the war. It remains unaltered in all its essential aerodynamic features and main dimensions, but has been slightly modified and fitted with a more powerful engine. This two-seater biplane is fitted with a fuselage of rectangular section, built up of ash longerons, which are channelled out between the strut attachments and strengthened by flanges of three-ply wood. At the rear, the fuselage terminates in a vertical knife edge carrying a sternpost to which is hinged a balanced rudder, which is of the usual Avro type, as are also the tail plane and elevators. A stout ash tail skid is also fitted to prevent damage by the ground. The front portion of the fuselage carries the engine, which is enclosed by a metal cowl, and the pilot and passenger's cockpits. The rotary type engine is supported in two steel plate bearers, mounted in the nose of the fuselage, while an inspection door provided on each side of the cowling permits of a general examination of the engine and its accessories. Immediately behind the engine the petrol and oil tanks are mounted, while there is also a small gravity tank fitted in the centre section of the main planes. This centre section, which is horizontal, is supported by two pairs of ash struts. from the fore part of the fuselage to the sides of which the main planes are attached. Four pairs of hollow spruce struts connect the upper and lower supporting surfaces, which are rigidly braced together, and have a pronounced stagger as well as a slight dihedral. The lift, landing, and incidence wires of the main planes are all of stranded steel cable, the lift wires being duplicated throughout, except in the inner front bays. The controls consist of a vertical lever pivoted on a longitudinal rocking shaft and a foot-bar operating the rudder through duplicated control wires. A fore-and-aft movement of the vertical lever operates the elevator, whilst a lateral motion actuates the ailerons. A complete dual control is fitted, and the switch system is arranged with a master switch in the pilot’s cockpit. The under-carriage comprises two pairs of hollow steel stream-line vee-struts, carrying on their lower extremities a stout ash skid, having a slight downward tilt forward. A tubular axle is fitted, from each end of which two steel tubes run to a cross-piece, whilst another single tube, pivoted to the lower longeron carries another cross-piece on its lower extremity. The springing of the wheels is effected by rubber shock absorbers, which connect the two cross-pieces and are enclosed in a stream-line metal casing. Clerget engine; weight (light), 1,231 lb.; weight (fully loaded), 1,829 lb.; loading, 5.54 lb. per sq. ft.; maximum speed, 95 miles per hour; cruising speed, 70 miles per hour; landing speed, 40 miles per hour. description: This model represents the small tractor biplane built by the Sopwith Aviation Co., towards the end of 1913. It was designed with the object of attaining very high speed together with capability of quick manœuvre. In 1914 this machine was utilised for military purposes, as, on account of its speed (92 miles per hour), it was specially suitable for scouting. The machine was of typical Sopwith design, being the forerunner of many models produced by this firm during the war (1914–18). The original biplane was fitted with an 80 h.p. Gnome engine. The top planes are secured to a centre panel supported above the fuselage by two pairs of struts; there are two other pairs of struts which separate the main planes near their extremities. The bottom planes are attached to the lower portion of the fuselage, which is of the usual Sopwith design. There is a slight dihedral angle, and the main planes are staggered to the extent of 1 foot.

description: This model represents the single-seater triplane constructed by the Sopwith Aviation Co., in 1916. It was designed with a view to attaining very high speed together with the capability of quick manœuvre, and was used successfully for scouting and fighting purposes during the war (1914–18). It was considered, at the time of its inception, to be one of the fastest machines in the world. The aeroplane is capable of climbing quickly to a considerable height, and this, together with its high speed, makes it very suitable for fighting purposes. The armament consists of one Vickers machine gun, arranged to fire through the airscrew. A 100 h.p. Clerget rotary engine is the power unit usually fitted. Note-worthy features of design are the arrangement of interplane struts and the relatively high aspect ratio of the planes. The struts are not duplicated, as is usual in multiplane construction, the necessary strength being provided by increasing their depth. They are only six in number, two forming the centre section. There is a pronounced stagger between the main planes. The fuselage, undercarriage, and tail plane are of usual Sopwith design.

description: This model represents a single-seater biplane constructed in 1918 by the Sopwith Aviation Co., for use against infantry in trench warfare. It was specially designed for low flying, the pilot being protected from machine-gune fire by 690 lb. of armour plate. The armament consisted of two Vickers machine guns arranged to fire through the tractor airscrew. This machine is particularly suitable for contact patrol work in connection with the advance of infantry, its rapid climb enabling it to be taken out of action when the objective is passed. When it is desired to attack, the nose of the machine is pointed at the target to enable the fixed guns to be brought into action. The two Vickers guns, which fire through the airscrew parallel to the line of flight, are actuated by the engine, a synchronising gear being used. The drive from the engine actuates a cam which gives motion to links and levers which operate the lever trigger bars of the guns. When the control levers are depressed the guns continue to fire at proper intervals until the pressure is released. A 228 b.h.p. rotary B.R. 2 engine is fitted.

description: Type V/1500. Scale approximately 1:24. Lent by Messrs. Handley Page Transport, Ltd., 1921. This model represents the large four-engined biplane built by Handley Page in 1918. It was designed originally for long-distance night bombing, but is easily convertible into a commercial vehicle by the removal of the guns, bombgear, &c., and by refitting the fuselage. When used for transport purposes it is capable of accommodating 45 passengers, in addition to a crew of three, and 10,000 lb. of goods, with fuel for 400 to 500 miles. The Handley Page biplane, type V/1500, was a development of the twin-engined bomber of 1916. It was designed to operate over long distances, the fuel capacity being for a 14 hours’ flight. The upper and lower planes of this machine are of equal span, but the latter has a slight dihedral. There is a decided sweep-back on both planes. The fuselage has a passage running along its whole length. A gunner’s cockpit is provided behind the tail plane, the armament so placed protecting the machine from a rear attack. description: This aeroplane, which was built at Weybridge, is the original machine on which the first direct trans-Atlantic flight was made by Captain Sir John Alcock, K.B.E., D.S.C., and Lieutenant Sir Arthur Whitten Brown, K.B.E., on the 14th–15th June, 1919, flying over a distance of 1,890 miles (3,041 kilometres) in 15 hours 57 minutes at an average speed of 118·5 miles, or 190·7 kilometres, per hour. This twin-engined biplane, which is inherently stable, was originally designed as a heavy bomber, and was slightly modified to enable it to accommodate sufficient fuel for the trans-Atlantic flight. The centre section of the main planes, which is horizontal, carries the two engines, each of which is enclosed, with its radiator and an oil tank, in a casing of approximately stream-line form, and supported between the wings by four vertical circular steel struts with wooden fairings. A service petrol tank is fitted in the centre section of the upper plane. The main planes on each side of the centre section have a dihedral angle of 3 degrees, and are set to an angle of incidence of 3½ degrees. The spars, which are of box section, are built up of spruce and three-ply and bound with fabric, while the interplane struts, with the exception of those carrying the engines, are of solid spruce. The upper and lower wings are of equal span and carry balanced ailerons. The fuselage is constructed in two parts, the forward portion ahead of the main plane rear spars being of steel tube, while the longerons of the rear portion are of McGruer’s patent wooden tube, and are braced with swaged steel tie-rods. The two seats are arranged side by side, immediately behind a large petrol tank, in the nose of the machine. The tail, which is fitted with two balanced rudders and two fins, is of biplane form, each plane being set at an angle of 2½ degrees with the axis of the fuselage, and fitted with an elevator in the rear. The undercarriage is in two parts, each of which comprises a V-type landing gear attached to the main planes beneath the engine bay. The power is provided by two 360 h.p. Rolls-Royce “ Eagle 8 ” engines, described in an adjacent label, each driving a four-bladed tractor airscrew through an epicyclic reduction gear.

description: The five full-size examples shown illustrate the construction of the framework of the main planes of some of the principal types of aeroplanes in use in 1910. *Farman Biplane.*—The framework consisted of two parallel transverse main spars of ash, which passed from one extremity of the plane to the other, and across which were fastened the curved ribs. The front spar was flush with the front or leading edge of the wing, but the ribs overlapped the rear spar by a distance of about 1.8 ft., and thus formed a flexible trailing edge. The special spars of I section were of white poplar. The maximum camber was 3.6 in. at a distance of one-quarter the chord from the front edge. *Wright Biplane.*—Two parallel transverse spars of spruce were employed, that at the front edge of the wing being rounded off, and here the connection between the spar and the ribs was strengthened by fitting a light metal strap round the spar and fastening it to the ribs. A flexible trailing edge was formed as in the Farman biplane. The ribs at the extremities of the wings were of less camber than those in the centre. The maximum camber was 4 in. at a distance of about 2.5 ft. from the front edge. *Wright-Clarke Glider.*—The construction of the framework is generally similar to that of the Wright biplane. The spars are of spruce and the front spar is rounded off to form a blunt cutting edge. The maximum camber is 3 in. *Clarke Surface.*—This construction was designed by Mr. T. W. K. Clarke. The main transverse spars are of channel section, built of ash. The spacing of the ribs is 9 in., and the maximum camber is 3 in. at a distance of one-third the chord from the front edge. This construction was copied from an actual standard Blériot monoplane at Brooklands, and represents a later type of surface than is shown on the model of Blériot XI (see No. 10). It has additional transverse stringer pieces running the whole length of each wing.

description: The examples exhibited illustrate different forms of hollow spar or wooden tube made according to the McGrueir system, for use in aeronautical work. The wood used for these spars is Pacific Coast spruce, chiefly because of its cleanliness, and even growth. Boards of any thickness between 1 in. and 4 in. are thoroughly saturated, and bent breadthwise over steam-heated tubes. The edges are made to meet in a scarf joint and glued with a waterproof glue. One or more layers may be used, glue being applied between the layers as well as at the joint. The spar is not a ply-wood construction, and no attempt is made to cross the fibres, which must all lie parallel with the length of the spar. Knots, swirls, and torse fibre are not permissible, as their presence would weaken the construction, which is particularly suited to withstand compressional stresses.

object_name: TRACTOR AIRSCREW, SHOWING METHOD OF CONSTRUCTION
description: Modern airscrews are built up of from four to eight separate laminations of walnut or mahogany, which are glued together stepwise. When set, the whole is pegged, and the sections at various points are worked out in accordance with the drawings, the remainder of the material being shaped in smooth curves to correspond. The four-bladed tractor airscrew shown, illustrates this process. The B.E. 2 type tractor airscrew represented is constructed of five laminæ of walnut glued together. One blade is shown in this, the first stage of manufacture. The second blade shows the glued-up block pegged and cut away, being shaped into curves to agree with the sections at various points previously determined from drawings. The third blade illustrates the stage prior to varnishing. The shaping to final section was accomplished by hand, special attention being paid to the leading and trailing edges. The pitch angle and blade section was checked, and the whole sand-papered and covered with a wood-filler. The fourth blade shows the airscrew in its finished state. The wood has been given two or three successive coats of copal varnish, being rubbed down after each coat with powdered pumice and a final coat of varnish applied.

description: This is a portion of the Blériot monoplane which first crossed the Irish Channel from Holyhead to Dublin on 26th April, 1912. The control is of the type patented by M. Blériot in 1908. The mechanism consists of a hand lever universally jointed to a bracket, which is supported by a platform on the fuselage. At the lower end of the lever is a bell-shaped fitting, called the “cloche,” to the edge of which four wires are attached at equal intervals. The fore-and-aft wires operate the rear elevator, whilst those at the side operate the wing warping. The latter control wires do not lead directly to the wing tips from the cloche, but are taken to a rocking lever, supported at the apex of an inverted triangular mast attached to the underside of the fuselage. This rocking lever actuates a drum, round which the wires to the wing tips are wound in opposite directions. The vertical hand lever also carries the ignition advance lever and a throttle lever. A pedal operates the rudder (see model of Blériot monoplane. No. 10). Inv.

description: This steam engine was constructed to provide power for propelling the model shown suspended from the ceiling (see No. 1). It was placed inside the car, at the after end, in a vertical position, and was connected with the propeller on the flying machine by endless cords running over the wooden pulleys shown. The framework consists of an angle-iron structure containing the bearings for the crank-shaft and supporting the cylinder. The boiler consisted of 50 inverted truncated cones arranged around and above the furnace, and connected with a steam drum; they presented 100 sq. ft. of heating surface. The air-cooled tubular condenser gave a vacuum of from 5 to 8 lb. The speed of this model engine was to be 300 revolutions per minute, and the actual engine was intended to develop 25 to 30 h.p.

description: The example shown is a four-cycle vertical cylinder engine, embodying the patents taken out by Mr. G. Green and others in 1904–5, and is especially designed for use on flying machines. This engine was entered for the Alexander Motor Prize Competition, 1911, and was awarded the prize of £1,000 offered by Mr. P. Y. Alexander. It has four cylinders, 140 mm. (5·5 in.) diameter by 146 mm. (5·85 in.) stroke, which, with their valve chambers, are separate steel castings, and are held to a closed aluminium crank chamber by lugs on the lower flanges of the cylinders. Copper water jackets are employed, and by the use of a special joint at their lower ends are free to expand and contract. A grooved flange formed on the cylinder contains a rubber ring, over which the jacket is forced by being slightly bell-mouthed. It is stated that the joint thus made is perfectly watertight, while allowing free movement of the jacket. The crank chamber is an aluminium casting, webbed on the inside to provide bearings for the crank-shaft, and having a separate lower portion attached to the casting by aluminium straps; this lower portion forms an oil sump. At one end of the crank-shaft, which is hollow, is a pair of gear wheels that drive the magneto and cam-shaft spindles. These wheels are enclosed by the end plate of the crank chamber, and on this plate is the bracket supporting the magneto and water pump. The cam-shaft, which is arranged above the cylinders, is driven from the crank-shaft by a vertical spindle at its end, a pair of bevel wheels at the top of the spindle and the gear wheels at the bottom forming the connecting links. Completely enclosing the cam-shaft is an aluminium case, providing bearings for its support, the case being itself supported by four brackets above the cylinders. The inlet and exhaust valves are of the mushroom type, mounted in cylindrical cages, and are held down by aluminium nuts, which form domes over the valve springs. The valves are operated from the cam-shaft by rocking levers pivoted on extensions of the cam-shaft casing. Auxiliary exhaust ports are provided in the cylinder walls just below the water jackets.

description: Presented by The Air Ministry, 1919. Plate V, No. 2. Inv. 1919-427. S.M. 1381. L.S.

This is an air-cooled eight-cylinder, V-type engine, and is similar in design to a Renault. It has several improvements, however, the chief of these being the mounting of the crank-shaft and cam-shaft on ball and roller bearings. Two branch pipes convey it to two of the main bearing caps, whence it flows outwards on either side to oiling rings or oil throwers fixed on to the crank webs. From these the oil is centrifugally forced through the crank-pins to the big end bearings. Splash lubrication only is provided for the main roller bearings and cylinders. The engine is cooled by the draught from the airscrew, combined with the draught due to the forward motion of the aeroplane. It is fitted with a cowl so that, when in flight, the air entering at the front can only escape round and between the fins on the cylinders. The gases from the two throttle chambers of a double Claudel-Hobson R.A.F.-type carburetter pass up through cored passages in the flywheel cover, and thence through copper induction pipes to the cylinders, while ignition is effected by two magnetos placed on a bracket on the flywheel cover. The principal data of the engine are: Normal b.h.p., 93; weight of engine, 450 lb.; bore, 100 mm.; stroke, 140 mm.; normal speed of rotation, 1,600 revolutions per minute; petrol consumption, 8.5 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 0.5 gallons per hour; order of firing, 1, 5, 3, 7, 4, 8, 2, 6. Inlet valve opens 1.5 mm. after top dead centre, and closes 16 mm. after bottom dead centre. Exhaust valve opens 22 mm. before bottom dead centre, and closes 1 mm. after top dead centre. Ignition occurs 12 mm. before top dead centre.

description: The “Cossack” is a development of the 12-cylinder Sunbeam engine which had four valves per cylinder, and is the first type of this engine in which the size of the cylinders was increased. It was specially designed for use in airships. It has 12 cast-iron cylinders arranged in two rows of six each, set in “V” formation at an angle of 60 degrees to each other. The cylinders are cast in blocks of three, and each cylinder is provided with two inlet valves and two exhaust valves of high chrome steel, which are operated by overhead cam-shafts, one to each set of valves, each shaft being driven by a train of gears from the crank-shaft. The connecting-rods are of the articulated pattern, of “H” section nickel chrome steel, and the pistons of aluminium. Lubrication is on the “dry base” principle, and is by gear-wheel pumps, three pumps being fitted. Carburation is effected by four Claudel-Hobson (C.Z.S. 42) carburetters, the petrol feed being by pressure or gravity. Ignition is by means of four B.T.H. (P.M. 6) magnetos furnishing independent sparks for two sparking plugs fitted to each cylinder. The engine is of the water-cooled type, the circulation being maintained by a centrifugal pump, while a special arrangement is also made for the exhaust to be water-cooled, a governor being fitted which automatically cuts off the ignition when the engine reaches a speed of 2,500 revolutions per minute, or when the oil pressure falls below 20 lb. per sq. in. The early types of this engine have two magnetos and covers, inside exhaust pipes, outside carburetters, geared propeller shaft, and air starter mechanism; but later types have four magnetos and covers, inside exhausts, outside carburetters, geared propeller, and air and hand starter.

description: This engine (the Bentley Rotary), which was designed by Captain W. O. Bentley, M.B.E., and produced by Messrs. Humber, Ltd., Coventry, was used extensively towards the end of the war (1914–1918). It is a nine-cylinder rotary air-cooled engine, the cylinders of which are of aluminium shrunk on to cast-iron liners, and arranged radially round a fixed crank-shaft. Each cylinder is provided at its lower end with five shallow stiffening ribs, above which is a series of deep radiating fins. The combustion heads, which are of machined steel, are made in one piece with the induction pockets, into which steel inlet valve guides are pressed, while the exhaust valve cages, into which cast-iron valve guides are pressed, are also in one piece with the heads. The cylinders and combustion heads are attached to the crank-case by four long bolts located at the corners of each cylinder, the cooling fins being cut away to allow clearance. The pistons are of aluminium alloy, have slightly concave heads, and are provided with five very shallow cast-iron rings set in grooves near the top of the piston. Holes are drilled in the piston skirt to allow the oil from inside the piston to escape on to the cylinder walls. The connecting-rods are of tubular section steel, and, with the exception of the master-rod, are bushed with phosphor bronze at both ends. The master rod is bushed with phosphor bronze at the piston end only, its large end riding on two ball-bearings mounted on the crank-pin. Inlet and exhaust valves are both operated by overhead rocker arms and tappets, each of which is connected to a push rod by a ball joint. The cam gear comprises two internally toothed rings known as “gear rings,” within which are the corresponding externally toothed gears. These gears have 16 teeth as against 18 of the “gear rings,” and the gears are thus driven at nine-eighths of engine speed, and overtake the gear rings once in eight revolutions. Each gear has four cams, so that in eight revolutions each tappet is lifted four times, i.e., once in every two revolutions. Forced lubrication is fitted, and oil from the pump is led to an orifice in the crank-shaft, through which it is conducted by a copper pipe to a duct in the base of the rear web of the hollow crank-pin. A bye-pass at the foot of the rear crank-pin supplies oil to the thrust box. The bulk of the oil forced along the pipe inside the crank-shaft travels up the duct in the rear web to the crank-pin, where the stream diverges again into supplies for the connecting-rod assembly, the pistons and the cylinders on the one hand, and for the cam gear-box on the other hand. The Blœctube carburetter is screwed on the extreme rear end of the hollow crank-shaft, through which the explosive mixture passes to the orifice at the foot of the rear web of the crank, whence it passes into the main crank-case. It is then sucked through a ring of holes into the gas chamber, which rotates with the thrust box and through the induction pipes, into the cylinders. Ignition is provided by two M.L. magnetos of the revolving armature type, giving two sparks per revolution. The principal data of the engine are: Normal b.h.p., 150; weight (dry), 408 lb.; normal revolutions per minute, 1,250; bore, 120 mm.; stroke, 170 mm.; petrol consumption, 13 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 1.5 gallons per hour; order of firing, 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 2, 4, 6, 8. Inlet valve opens 5 degrees before top dead centre and closes 58 degrees after bottom dead centre; exhaust valve opens 72 degrees before bottom dead centre and closes 7 degrees after top dead centre. Ignition occurs at 22.5 degrees before top dead centre.

description: This water-cooled engine of the vertical type comprises six cylinders, cast in two blocks of three, and was made by the Siddeley Deasy Motor Co., Ltd., Coventry. Each casting forms the cylinder heads, water jackets, valve passages and inlet manifold of three cylinders, into which steel liners are fitted forming the working barrels. Near the level of the combustion chamber the jackets are divided horizontally into two portions, which are bolted together. Leakage is prevented at the base of the aluminium jacket by means of a rubber ring, pressed against a shoulder of the steel liner by a castellated ring-nut screwed into the jacket. The cylinder heads are flat, and each carries a large nickel-steel inlet valve and two smaller tungsten-steel exhaust valves, all operated by a single hollow cam-shaft, the exhaust valves being operated directly and the inlet valves through the agency of a small rocking lever. The pistons are die cast from an aluminium alloy, and each carries three cast-iron rings near the head, and a scraper ring in the skirt. High-tensile steel connecting-rods, machined to H section, connect with the six-cylinder seven-bearing type crank-shaft, the cranks of which are spaced 120 degrees apart. The crank-case is in two portions, the upper portion, which is stiffened by cross webs, is formed integral with the housings of the crank-shaft bearings, and carries the eight supporting feet of the engine, in addition to the main lubrication filter and two breathers. The lower half acts as an oil sump and a cover for the moving parts, and is furnished with sharply inclined gutters, which ensure that the filter remains constantly submerged in oil. Lubrication is by means of two pumps, driven by a vertical shaft, which operates the whole of the accessories. The upper pump draws oil from an external tank, and forces it by way of a filter into a manifold, which, by means of branch pipes, supplies oil to the journal bearings, the thrust housing, the vertical shaft, and the skew gearing operating the magnetos. Oil fed to the main crank-shaft bearings passes into the hollow journals, and by way of holes drilled in the crank-webs, to the crank pins, whence it is flung on to the cylinder walls and the little ends of the connecting-rods. From the front end of the manifold a small pipe conveys oil through the hollow cam-shaft to the cam-shaft bearings, when it is flung on to the cams, rocking levers, and valve heads. Oil which collects in the base of the chamber is drawn out by the second pump and delivered back to the oil tank. Two independent sparking plugs are fitted in each cylinder, one set being connected to a Fellows E.M. 6 type magneto, the second set being served by a small six-volt battery, through a Remy combined contact breaker and distributer mounted at the rear end of the cam-shaft housing, and a coil carried on other magneto platform. Two Zenith carburetters are fitted. The principal data of the engine are: Normal b.h.p., 246; maximum b.h.p., 255; bore, 145 mm.; stroke, 190 mm.; normal revolutions per minute, 1,400; weight (without cooling water), 625 lb.; oil consumption, 1·8 gallons per hour; petrol consumption, 17 gallons per hour; order of firing, 1, 5, 3, 6, 2, 4; valve timing, inlet valve opens 7 degrees after top dead centre and closes 43 degrees after bottom dead centre; exhaust valve opens 58 degrees before bottom dead centre and closes 12 degrees after top dead centre; ignition occurs at maximum advance, 37½ degrees before top dead centre. description: The engine here exhibited is the port engine of the Vickers-Vimy Rolls-Royce aeroplane which made the first direct trans-Atlantic flight on 14th to 15th June, 1919 (see No. 26). The starboard engine remains installed in the aeroplane. It is a 12-cylinder V-type, water-cooled, left-hand tractor engine, in which the two sets of cylinders are arranged at an angle of 60 degrees. The cylinders are of special wrought steel construction, and the pistons, which are specially designed for high compression, are each fitted with four piston rings. There is an oil scraper at the bottom of each piston. The pistons of opposite cylinders are operated by master and articulated connecting-rods respectively and work on a six-throw crank-shaft. Explosive mixture is supplied to the cylinders by four Rolls-Royce Claudel-Hobson carburetters, fitted with a high-altitude control, and ignition is effected by four six-cylinder Watford magnetos, each cylinder being provided with two ignition plugs. A four-bladed tractor airscrew is driven through an epicylic reduction gear of ·6 to 1. The principal data of the engine are: Bore, 4·5 in.; stroke, 6·5 in.; normal b.h.p., 360; weight of engine, 900 lb.; normal speed, 1,800 revolutions per minute; normal airscrew speed, 1,080 revolutions per minute; diameter of airscrew, 10 ft. 3 in. description: This engine was fitted to the first British military airship, “Nulli Secundus,” in 1907. It is of the V-type, with eight cylinders arranged in planes at right angles to one another, four on each side of the crank-shaft. The cylinders are steel forgings, and are mounted on an aluminium crank-chamber and held by loose yokes at their flanges. The cylinder heads contain the inlet and exhaust valves; the former are atmospheric, while the latter are mechanically operated. No carburetter is employed, the petrol being supplied direct to the inlet valves by means of a pump. Brass water jackets are shown on the example, but electrolytically deposited copper is now usually employed. A feature of this type of motor is the cooling arrangement. Very little water is carried, the water being converted into steam, which is then condensed by a tubular condenser, not shown with the engine exhibited. Splash lubrication is employed, the oil pump, water pump, and variable-throw fuel pump being all driven by belts direct from the crank-shaft. Ignition is performed by means of an accumulator in conjunction with a distributer mounted on the crank-chamber and driven by the cam-shaft. The latter is driven by exposed gearing. On the dirigible balloon "Nulli Secundus" two two-bladed propellers, 10 ft. diameter, were employed, and were driven by long belts running over wire-spoked pulley wheels. The balloon was made of gold-beaters' skin, and had a length of 100 ft., a diameter of 30 ft., and a capacity of 60,000 cu. ft. Hydrogen was employed as the lifting agent.

description: The example shown is an air-cooled three-cylinder semi-radial petrol engine of the type used by M. L. Blériot in 1909 in his cross-Channel flight. It is of simple design, and is one of the smallest engines yet fitted to an aeroplane. The cylinders, each with its head and valve chamber, are separate castings, and are ribbed circumferentially in order to provide a large cooling surface. They are attached to an aluminium crank-chamber, which is cast in halves, the portions being held together by long through bolts. The angle between adjacent cylinders is 60 degrees, and the order of ignition is 1, 3, 2, taking No. 2 cylinder as the vertical central one. Atmospheric induction valves, situated above the exhaust valves, are employed; the latter are operated by separate cam-shafts. Auxiliary exhaust ports are provided in the cylinder walls, which are uncovered by the pistons at the ends of their strokes. The connecting-rods are coupled to the common crank-pin, two of the big ends being forked to allow of this. A balanced flywheel is provided to compensate for the reversal of the vertical cylinder. The carburetter is of the float feed type, and is provided with a conical choke tube, through which air enters at its lower end. It is possible to remove the jet through the inclined tube by withdrawing a plug situated in the throat of the choke tube. Additional air supply is provided for by a number of holes drilled round the base of an annulus in the mixing chamber. The holes are covered normally by balls held in position by a cover plate, and as the suction increases the balls rise from their seats. Petrol is fed by gravity from a cylindrical tank, the rear end of which contains lubricating oil. Particulars of the engine exhibited are : Diameter of cylinder, 105 mm. (4·13 in.) ; stroke, 130 mm. (5·1 in.) ; weight, with accessories, 65 kilo. (143 lb.) ; the shaft h.p. is 25 when running at 1,600 revolutions per minute. As fitted to the cross-Channel monoplane, the engine runs in a left-handed direction when looking towards the propeller from the front of the machine. The propeller then employed was of the Chauvière laminated type, in walnut, 6·66 ft. diameter.

description: The "Gnome" motor is of French design, and has materially assisted towards solving the problem of obtaining a reliable aeroplane engine which is capable of developing sufficient horse-power without excessive weight. In this type of motor the crank-shaft is stationary, and the cylinders and crank-chamber revolve round it. The example shown, which has been removed from the "Birdling" monoplane (see No. 17), has nickel-steel cylinders 4.3 in. diameter by 4.7 in. stroke, machined with their air-cooling ribs out of the solid. The crank-chamber is also of steel, and the seven cylinders are held in position by split-steel rings, which are sprung into grooves turned in the cylinders, so that the cylinders cannot be withdrawn without removing the rings. Taper-pins of special section, which pass through the rim of the crank-chamber, securely lock these rings in position. Piston-rings of L-section brass are employed, similar in shape to the cup-leather of an hydraulic piston. The end plate, on which the propeller is fixed when used, as in the example, as a tractor screw, carries on the inside the cams and gear-wheels which operate the exhaust valve rods. Ball-bearings are used to support the engine as a whole upon the stationary crank-shaft, and a thrust block is provided at the rear end of the engine. The connecting-rods all operate on a single crank-pin. The big end of one of them, embracing the crank and mounted on ball-bearings, is formed into a cage, the outer rings of which carry the plain bearings for the remaining six connecting-rods. The carburetter, which is stationary, is of the single-jet type, and feeds the engine through the hollow crank-shaft, petrol flowing thence into the crank-chamber, from which each cylinder obtains its mixture by means of an automatic inlet valve of the mushroom type situated in the piston-head. The valve seating also acts as a means of connection between the piston and the connecting-rod. The exhaust valves are situated in the cylinder heads, and are operated by twin balanced rocking levers actuated by long push rods connected with the cams contained in the end plate of the crank-chamber. The cams consist of seven flat steel collars with a common boss keyed on to a spindle and operated by an epicyclic train of wheels, the fixed wheel being on the end of the stationary crank-shaft. Both the inlet and the exhaust valves are balanced against centrifugal force by means of counterweights. An odd number of cylinders is necessary in order that the firing of the mixture in each cylinder may be carried out at equal angular intervals, and thus give an even torque, e.g., if the mixture in cylinder No. 1 was fired first, the order of firing would be 1, 3, 5, 7, 2, 4, 6, and repeat. Ignition is effected by a Bosch high-tension magneto, mounted on a stationary bracket in an inverted position and driven by gearing. The distribution of the electric current to the sparking-plugs is effected by a revolving commutator plate and a stationary brush. Firing of the charge occurs just before the cylinder concerned reaches its highest position, the piston then being at the top of its stroke. Bare brass wires are employed as connections between the sparking-plugs and the commutator. Lubrication is provided for by a reciprocating pump driven in a similar manner to the magneto, and mounted on the same plate. Castor oil only is used, and is injected into the hollow crank-shaft through sight-feed fittings, and from thence to each cylinder. When running at the normal speed of 1,200 revolutions per minute, the engine develops 50 b.h.p. The ratio of engine weight to horse-power is about 3 : 1. S.M. 1419. L.S.

description: This engine is a development of the ordinary Gnome engine, and, as its name implies, is provided with only one valve in each cylinder—a mechanically operated exhaust valve situated in the cylinder head. It is a nine-cylinder rotary air-cooled engine, the cylinders being arranged radially and symmetrically round the fixed crank-shaft. The cylinders, which are of nickel chrome steel, are machined from the solid, while the pistons are of cast-iron, each having a thick concave crown connected solidly by webs to the gudgeon-pin bosses. A hollow steel gudgeon-pin is fixed in the piston boss by a single steel set-screw with a conical prolongation. The crank-case, which is in two portions, comprises two steel castings secured together by nine bolts; the cylinders are located by keys, and held by a recess turned in the bottom of each. The inner ends of the cylinders project into the crank-case, and contain a belt of ports, overrun by the piston when near the bottom of its stroke, and thereby functioning as an inlet valve. The massive steel cone-seated exhaust valve, which is situated in the cylinder head, is actuated by a rocker and push rod, the centrifugal effect of which balances that of the valve. An improved form of lubrication is fitted in this type of engine, by means of which the gudgeon bearings are supplied with oil passing outwards from the big end cage along the hollow webs of the connecting-rods, while the oil exuding from the gudgeon bearing is led by two ducts to the cylinder walls. The cam sleeve, cams, and cam-shaft gears are also positively lubricated by oil supplied from the crank-shaft through a series of ducts. The petrol is pressure-fed from the tank to a copper pipe running inside the crank-shaft, thence through the centre of the large crank-web, hollow crank-pin, and small crank-web, to the petrol jet, which is situated in the crank-case, where the mixture is so rich as to be non-explosive. Air is admitted into the cylinder through the exhaust valve, while the rich mixture enters by way of the belt of ports at the inner end of the cylinder. A Bosch magneto of the D.A.L. type is fitted. The principal data of the engine are: Normal b.h.p., 105; weight, 297 lb.; speed, 1,200 revolutions per minute; bore, 110 mm.; stroke, 150 mm.; petrol consumption, 10 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 2 gallons per hour; order of firing, 1, 3, 5, 9, 2, 4, 6, 8 (the cylinders are numbered 1 to 9 consecutively, in a clockwise direction when facing the propeller). Cylinder ports open 20 degrees before bottom dead centre and close 20 degrees after bottom dead centre; exhaust valve opens 85 degrees after top dead centre and closes 60 degrees before bottom dead centre (the exhaust valve being open continuously during 395 degrees of rotation). Ignition occurs 18 degrees before top dead centre. Inv.

description: This engine was originally designed by Messrs. Renault Frères, France, and was afterwards produced in large numbers by several makers in this country. It may be used either on a tractor or propeller machine, and is an eight-cylinder V-type air-cooled engine, with the two sets of cylinders arranged at an angle of 90 degrees with each other, the cylinders being set directly opposite one another. The cylinders and cylinder heads are separate, both being of cast iron, with air-cooling fins cast on each, and they are secured to the crank-case by means of a clamp, which is held by long studs projecting up from the crank-case. An inlet valve is provided at the side of each cylinder, and works in a valve cage, which also forms the elbow for the inlet pipe, being operated directly by a tappet from the cam-shaft. The exhaust valve works in the cylinder head, and is operated by an overhead rocking lever and push rod. The steel pistons are each fitted with three cast-iron piston rings and a hardened steel gudgeon-pin. Opposite cylinders being in line, the pressure from the pistons of both is taken on one big end, one piston being fitted with the main rod and the other with an auxiliary rod, which transmits its pressure by the lower end working on a hardened steel pin attached to the main big end. The four-throw crank-shaft is carried in five bearings, the centre and two intermediate ones being gun-metal lined with white metal, and the outer ones ball bearings. The crank-case is of aluminium, and is divided into two portions horizontally along the centre line of the crank-shaft, the upper portion containing the bearings, cam-shaft, and gears, and the lower portion forming an oil base and carrying the oil pump, strainer, and oil-pressure release valve. A breather is fitted on the top of the crank-case between the cylinders. The engine is fitted with a Claudel-Hobson carburetter of the R.A.F. type, and an eight-cylinder B.T.H. A.8-type magneto. The cam-shaft and propeller-shaft are made on the divided principle, and are driven from the crank-shaft through a reduction gear of 2 to 1. The order of firing is 1, 5, 3, 7, 4, 8, 2, 6. (These numbers are painted on the cylinders for reference.) description: This radial air-cooled engine of double-star formation is a development of the early three-cylinder type, and is made by the British Anzani Engine Co., Ltd. The engine consists of two groups each of five cylinders, each group forming a five-branch star in a plane perpendicular to the engine axis. The axes of the cylinders of the two groups are arranged alternately, so that the whole engine from the front has the appearance of a regular star with ten points. The cylinders, which are of cast iron, have ribs of special section, and are secured by means of small columns passing through lugs cast solid with the cylinder. The cast-iron pistons are machined internally and externally to reduce weight, and are each fitted with two patent conically-seated piston rings. The nickel steel connecting-rods of H section drive on to a hollow nickel chrome steel two-throw crank-shaft running in two ball-bearing journals. Two nickel steel valves are fitted in each cylinder head, the exhaust valve being operated by a rocking lever, while the inlet valve is automatic. The shell-pattern aluminium crank-case is made in two halves, strongly ribbed internally and externally, and bolted together with long through bolts. Forced lubrication is fitted, and oil is pumped under pressure to the crank-shaft bearings, and thence to the big ends of the connecting-rods, through holes drilled in the webs and pins. The oil being here atomatised by centrifugal force, fills the crank-case with a mist of oil, which thoroughly lubricates the pistons, gudgeon-pins, and all moving parts. The oil pump is enclosed in a watertight compartment cast solid with the valve-gear cover. The explosive mixture is supplied to the cylinders through radial pipes lodged in a groove formed in the ribs, the radial pipes entering the crank-case and drawing gas from a supply chamber, at the lower end of which the gases enter from a Zenith carburetter. Dual ignition is fitted, and is effected by means of two high-tension magnetos of the Watford type. The data of the engine are : Weight, 363 lb. ; power developed, 100 h.p. ; bore, 105 mm. ; stroke, 145 mm. ; angle between cylinders, 36 degrees ; normal rotational speed, 1,250 revolutions per minute ; petrol consumption, 7 gallons per hour ; oil consumption, 2 gallons per hour. The cylinders fire successively in the following order, in a direction opposite to that in which the shaft rotates, 1, 8, 5, 2, 9, 6, 3, 10, 7, 4. Exhaust valve opens 45 mm. before bottom dead centre and closes 3 mm. after top dead centre. Ignition occurs 6 to 10 mm. before top dead centre.

description: The Clerget engine was designed and built by Clerget, Blin et Cie., France. The engine is of the rotary type, having seven steel cylinders provided with fins for air cooling. The inlet and exhaust valves are situated in the cylinder head, and are mechanically operated independently by push rods and rockers actuated by two eccentrics, which are keyed to the extension shaft. Each piston is provided with three cast-iron cut rings, in addition to double obturator rings of special silver alloy, and drives an independent hollow steel connecting-rod. One of these, called the main rod, is continuous with the banjo at the crank end, and holds all the pistons in their correct relative positions. The hollow steel crank-shaft, which is coned and keyed for attachment to the central support, is always fixed with the crank-pin on the top centre, and is held in position by a locked sleeve nut. An oil pump ensures efficient lubrication, and a M.L. type magneto is fitted. Mixture is supplied to the cylinders through radial external induction pipes from a simple form of carburetter, which is screwed on the end of the crank-shaft, the air being regulated by a butterfly valve controlled by a lever, while the petrol jet is not adjustable. The airscrew is driven directly from the crank-shaft.

description: The “Salmson” aero engines, invented jointly by MM. Canton and Unné, are manufactured on the Continent by the Société Anonyme des Moteurs “Salmson,” of Billancourt, Seine, and in Great Britain by the Dudbridge Iron Works, Ltd., of Stroud, Gloucester. The engine here exhibited is a nine-cylinder water-cooled engine of the radial type. The cylinders, which are placed symmetrically around the crank-shaft, are of nickel steel machined from solid forgings, the finished thickness of the working barrels being 2 mm. The flat-topped combustion chambers carry bosses into which the casings of the mechanically operated inlet and exhaust valves are screwed. Water jackets of spun copper are brazed to the cylinders and corrugated to permit the working barrels to expand freely. The flat-topped cast-iron pistons are each fitted with three cast-iron spring rings, and are secured by hollow tungsten steel gudgeon-pins to H section steel connecting-rods, all of which operate on one crank-pin by means of a steel cage or connecting rod carrier. The aluminium crank-case is in halves, between which the cylinders are securely clamped and from which the cam-box is detachable. The lubrication is forced, a double pump being fitted below the cam-box; one pump draws oil from the crank-case sump, and delivers it to an external reservoir, where it is cooled, and from where it is drawn by the other pump through a fine wire gauze filtering screen to a sight feed box, whence it is delivered by means of the crank-shaft and cam-box to the big ends, and by exudation to the pistons and gudgeon-pins. Two specially designed Zenith carburetters placed on the horizontal axis of the engine, deliver the explosive mixture through hot-water jacket branches into an annular mixing chamber, and thence by the induction pipes to the several cylinders, in which ignition is effected by a Siemens’ magneto. The engine drives through a reduction gear of 9 to 5, thereby allowing a propeller of larger diameter to be employed. The data of the engine are:—Weight, 360 lb. without radiator; normal b.h.p., 130 h.p.; bore, 4.73 in.; stroke, 5.52 in.; normal rational speed, 1,250 revolutions per minute; angle between cylinders, 40 degrees; petrol consumption, 9.5 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 0.5 gallons per hour; order of firing, 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 2, 4, 6, 8. Inlet valve opens 1 to 2 mm. before top dead centre and closes 18 to 20 mm. after bottom dead centre. Exhaust valve opens 18 to 20 mm. before bottom dead centre and closes 1 to 2 mm. before top dead centre. Ignition occurs 12 to 13 mm. before top dead centre.

description: This engine was designed by the Wright Brothers, and made by Leon Bollée in 1909. It was fitted to a Wright biplane of the 1908 type, constructed by Messrs. Short Brothers, and was in use from 1909 till 1913. The engine showed a departure from standard practice in that no carburetter was fitted, the petrol being squirted into the induction manifold by means of a small gear pump (not shown). The control of the engine was effected by switching off the current or by lifting the exhaust valves. The four separately cast cylinders are fitted with detachable water jackets, and are mounted on an aluminium crank-case. Automatic inlet valves are employed. The exhaust valves are operated by a simple vertical spindle and rocker arm. The pump supplying petrol to the induction manifold was placed on the on the right-hand side of the engine, being driven by worm gear from the cam-shaft. The lubricating oil pump (not shown) was on the same side and driven in like manner. It supplied oil to the main bearings from the reservoir in the base of the crank-case. The oil returned to the reservoir by a small pipe with a sight tube on the left of the crank-case, being filtered in passing. Ignition was by means of a high-tension Eisemann magneto, driven from the forward end of the cam-shaft. The water for cooling the engine was circulated by a rotary pump (not shown), mounted on the forward end of the main shaft. This engine has a free exhaust, and has also auxiliary exhaust ports in the cylinders which are uncovered when the piston is at the end of its stroke. The principal data are: Weight, 1,200 lb.; brake h.p., 30; normal speed of rotation, 1,650 revolutions per minute; bore, 112 mm.; stroke, 100 mm. The engine may be seen in position on the model of the Wright flying machine (see No. 7). Inv. 1920-383. S.M. 1382. L.S.

description: The engine here exhibited is a typical example of the various types produced by the Curtiss Motor Co., and used largely in America. It is an eight-cylinder V-type water-cooled engine divided into two groups of four cylinders set at 90 degrees. The cast-iron cylinders, which are cast separately, are each attached to the crank-case by eight short studs and four long through bolts, the latter being secured at the top to a bridge or yoke fitting over the cylinder heads. The cast-iron valves having electro-welded steel stems are located in the cylinder heads, and are operated by push rods and rocker arms from a single hollow cam-shaft in the crank-case between the cylinders, the push rods operating the exhaust valves being within tubular push rods operating the inlet valves. The valves, guides, and seats are cast integral with the cylinders, and the combustion chamber is nearly hemispherical. The water jackets are made of "monel," a non-corrosive combination of nickel and copper, and are oxyacetylene welded to the cylinder walls, the whole of the cylinder and jacket being nickel plated. The cooling water is circulated by means of a centrifugal pump, mounted on an extension of the crank-shaft projecting through the crank-case. Lubrication is effected by means of a force pump driven by bevel gearing from a wheel formed integral with the crank-shaft. The pump forces oil through the crank-shaft to the five main bearings, and through the cam-shaft to the latter's bearings, while oil slingers are fitted at each end of the crank-shaft. The lower half of the crank-case is divided into four compartments, which serve as an oil reservoir having a capacity of six hours' flight. The Berling D-81 magneto is mounted between the cylinders, and is driven from the cam-shaft gearing. A Schebler carburetter is fitted. The principal data of the engine are: Normal b.h.p., 90; weight, 325 lb.; bore, 4 in.; stroke, 5 in.; normal speed, 1,200 revolutions per minute; maximum speed, 1,450 revolutions per minute; petrol consumption, 7 gallons per hour; oil consumption, 0.25 gallon per hour. The order of firing of the cylinders is 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8, 5, 6; inlet valve closes 13/32 in. after bottom dead centre, exhaust valve opens 11/16 in. before bottom dead centre. Ignition occurs when fully advanced 0.5 in. before top dead centre.
