description: This successful engine was designed by La Sociedad Hispano-Suiza, Barcelona, Spain, and was also built by a large number of firms in France, England, and America. The cylinders are arranged in groups of four, the cylinders of each group forming a block which is of built-up construction. The water jackets and valve ports are cast of aluminium, and the individual heat treated steel liners of the cylinders are threaded into the aluminium castings. The crank-case is in two halves, divided horizontally on the centre line of the crank-shaft, the lower portion forming an oil base. Lubrication is by a positive pressure system, the oil being forced through a filter and by way of steel tubes cast in the crank-case, to the main bearings, and through the crank-shaft to the crank-pins. A Zenith duplex carburetter is fitted and two eight-cylinder mag- netos effect dual ignition.

description: Following the usual German aero engine practice, this engine is of the six-cylinder vertical, water-cooled type. Each separate cylinder is bolted to the crank-case by long studs, which pass through the top half of the crank-chamber and secure the crank-shaft bearings between the top and bottom halves of the crank-chamber. Two inlet and two exhaust valves are fitted in the head of each cylinder, and are operated by overhead valve rockers and by push rods on either side of the cylinders. The two cam-shafts, which run on plain bearings, are neatly arranged inside of the top half of the crank-case, and the floating exhaust cam-shaft is provided with half-compression cams. The pistons are of cast iron, fitted with three exceptionally wide rings, and the piston heads are supported by conical steel forgings riveted and welded to the piston crowns, which bear on the centre portion of the gudgeon-pins, through slots cut in the connecting-rod small ends. Two separate two-jet carbureters are fitted, having their intake passages through the top half of the crank-case casting, and each supplying three cylinders through an independent branched induction pipe, built up of light aluminium tube. The lubrication of the crank-shaft and connecting-rod bearings is effected by a gear pump working in an auxiliary oil reservoir formed in the bottom of the air-cooled base chamber. An oil-sealed petrol pump driven off the rear end of the inlet cam-shaft supplies petrol to the carbureters in conjunction with a supplementary pressure reservoir enclosed in the main petrol tank.

description: The Opel Argus engine is of the six-cylinder vertical, water-cooled type, and was produced in large quantities during the last two years of the war. The cylinders are arranged in three monoblocs, each pair of cylinders being mounted as a separate unit, with a common water jacket. The cylinder heads are flat and integral with the cylinder barrels, and the walls of the combustion space are formed by an increase in diameter of the barrels. In each cylinder block the two inlet valves are situated innermost, with their pockets opening to one side of the engine, while the two exhaust valves are outermost and deliver to a manifold on the opposite side. In the early forms of this engine cast-iron pistons were employed, but later aluminium pistons were fitted. The connecting-rods are of the normal H-section, but with the big and little ends offset in opposite directions. The crank-shaft is of the six-throw unbalanced type, and runs in seven white metalled phosphor-bronze bearings, housed between the upper and lower halves of the crank-case. The throws and journals are hollow and are closed by discs forced into recesses machined therein. The crank-case is of aluminium alloy, and is divided into a horizontal plane through the axis of the crank-shaft, the two halves being secured together by a flanged joint and numerous bolts, and also by 16 supporting studs. Dome-headed poppet valves are employed for both inlet and exhaust valves, which are operated by a cam-shaft carried in the upper half of the crank-case. The cylinders are served by two Zenith Opel curburetters, each of which serves three cylinders by a separate manifold. A compound oil pump fitted in the base of the sump is of the plunger type and consists of four pumps built as a unit, to pressure-feed the crank-shaft bearings and to act as feed pump and scavenge pump. description: This is a sectioned example of the A.V. 8 S. type of polar inductor magneto. It is suitable for an eight-cylinder aircraft engine. Examples of the materials used in construction are shown adjacent. This type of magneto has a stationary armature and a rotor consisting of four iron masses mounted upon a "straight-through" shaft of non-magnetic steel. The current which produces the spark is generated in the stationary armature, and reaches its maximum four times during each revolution of the rotor or polar inductor; accordingly four sparks are produced per revolution. The masses of iron which form the polar inductor are alternately North and South poles, so that in sweeping past the ends or poles of the laminated circuit, they cause, on each occasion, a reversion in the flux. The beginning of the primary winding is connected to the armature core and the end to the secondary winding and to the contact breaker. A cam operates the rocker arm, separating the contacts four times per revolution of the shaft. When the contacts are closed the primary winding is short-circuited, and, as the inductor rotates, the current induced in the primary winding builds up until the cam separates the contacts at the instant when this current is at a maximum. The instantaneous collapse and reversal of the flux at the moment of "break" produces the high voltage in the secondary winding which causes the spark. The distributor consists of a rotating metal brush, which conveys the high-tension current to the various segments; the sparks are thus distributed to the various plugs on the engine. A condenser is fitted above the armature, and a safety spark gap is provided between a point on the metal brush-box and a stud on the half-speed gear wheel. The inductor shaft is driven at engine speed. S.M. 116I. L.S.

description: This is a sectioned example of the lubricator patented by Mr. T. B. Murray and the makers in 1905. It was designed for use on aeroplane engines, where compactness and lightness are essential. The lubricator delivers oil under pressure to fourteen different points, the delivery to each being capable of independent regulation. The lubricator consists of an oil container, on the bottom of which are formed two circular discs, each having in its surface 14 holes arranged in a circle, alternate holes leading to the oil container and to one of the delivery pipes. Rotating over the discs, and kept in close contact with them by coiled springs, are two other discs driven by a worm lying between them and engaging with teeth cut in their peripheries. Each disc carries a vertical single-acting pump, the plunger of which is depressed by a series of cams fixed to the top of the container and returned by a helical spring surrounding the plunger. As the disc revolves and the pump comes over a hole connected with the reservoir, the plunger rises under the action of the spring, and oil is sucked into the barrel. As the pump is carried further, it comes over a delivery port and the plunger, which has a roller at its upper end, is forced down by a cam and the charge of oil is expelled. This action takes place seven times per revolution of each disc. The distance through which the plunger rises on the suction stroke can be adjusted by screws attached to the highest flat portions of the cam race, so that the amount of oil drawn in can be regulated. The drive is taken from the engine to the worm shaft by a vertical shaft and bevel gearing.

description: This is an example of the well-known carburetter manufactured by the Zenith Carburetter Co., and used extensively with aero engines. The chief characteristic is the fitting of an auxiliary or compensating jet in addition to the main jet. It has also a slow-running device and removable choke tube. The carburetter shown is suitable for a four-cylinder engine. The main jet is fitted in the centre of the compensating jet, being inserted from beneath when the plug is removed. It is fed directly from the float chamber. The compensating jet is inserted from above, and can be seen in position covering the main jet. The bore of each jet is marked on it in hundredths of a millimeter, so that a very fine adjustment can be effected by discriminate changing. The slow-running device consists of a small jet situated in a tube, which is part of the carburetter casting, and adjacent to the main intake. It has an air intake above it, through two holes in the casting, which can be plainly seen. At low-engine speeds, when the throttle, which is of the ordinary central-pivoted type, is almost closed, the slow-running device comes into operation and gases are sucked into the main intake from the small jet through a passage above the throttle. In this position the main and compensating jets are practically shut off, and the partial vacuum induced by the engine has its full effect upon the small jet. As the throttle is opened the slow-running device is progressively cut out. The mixture is kept more or less constant at all speeds by means of the compensating jet, which corrects the irregularities of the main jet; it has a greater influence at low speeds, while the main jet has most effect at high speeds. Adjustment is effected by changing the choke tube, the main and compensating jets, and regulating the slow-running device. An advantage of this carburetter is that, when once properly adjusted, it requires no attention, unless the conditions of service are radically altered.

description: This type of carburetter was used considerably on aircraft engines during the war (1914–18). The example shown is of a type supplied to the Royal Air Force, and is known as Mark I.A. It has two jets, mixing chambers, throttles, etc., but one common float chamber. The carburetter is suitable for an eight-cylinder (80 h.p.) Vee engine. The principal feature of this twin carburetter is the automatic mixture control, obtained by means of the specially designed cylindrical throttle, which forms a variable choke tube as it is opened. The main jets have holes in their outer casings through which the air for atomizing the petrol passes. Adjustment for strength of mixture is provided by two screws fitted just above each air intake. When these are screwed in, the actual suction on the jet is increased and the mixture is enriched. Provision is made for shutting off all the air for starting purposes. This is effected by the fitting of a central-pivoted throttle in each air intake. A large straining device and sump is arranged at the base of the carburetter, the petrol being fed directly from this to the float chamber. The two throttles are connected in such a manner that an equal opening is obtained.

description: This is a radiator of the ordinary honeycomb type, used extensively on motor-cars, but specially manufactured for aircraft use. Two of these radiators are fitted in front of the two power units on the D.H. 10 aeroplane. The cooling efficiency of the radiator can be regulated by means of the metal shutter (see No. 77). The radiator is fitted, at the top, with a screw-capped filler. The outlet pipe from the engine, which returns the water, circulated by a pump, to the radiator, has its entry just below this filler. At the centre, the radiator is cut away to allow for the engine shaft, which carries a tractor air screw immediately in front of the cooling surface. The inlet pipe to the engine is fitted at the base. The radiator is provided with lugs which engage with the engine bearers, and it is supported in this manner.

description: This shutter was designed by Captain L. C. Bygrave for the shielding of radiators when exposed to very low temperatures. The effect of a low temperature on an uncovered radiator is to cause over-cooling and consequent loss of engine efficiency. The shutter consists of a series of metal strips pivoted laterally and arranged in the manner of the slats on a Venetian blind. The maximum opening is when the strips are horizontal, and in this position the radiator has the full benefit of the cooling draft induced by its passage through the air and by any head wind which may be blowing. If over-cooling takes place the shutter may be partially or completely closed by means of the control in the pilot's cockpit. This device is often found useful in the intial stages of a flight, when it is desired to heat up the engine quickly.

description: This was the standard type of compass for scout machines, and was used extensively during the war (1914–18). It can be read with ease, as the moving part comes to rest quickly. The instrument is electrically illuminated, and the markings are treated with radium compound, which enables readings to be taken should the light fail. The compass is fitted with an inclined ring card graduated on the inside to read against the vertical pin in the centre, and on the outside to read against the "lubber line" on the glass. This liquid is introduced to steady the moving part. The period is about 10 seconds. S.M. 1389. L.S.

description: This was the standard magnetic compass used by the Royal Air Force. It is of the "quick-period" type, the moving part coming to rest almost immediately after a change of direction. The instrument is electrically illuminated, and the markings are treated with radium compound to enable readings to be taken should the light fail. The compass is fitted with an inclined ring card graduated on the inside to read against a forward "lubber line." The ring card is attached to the pivot by a wire framework which carries a system of parallel magnetic needles, and the whole is enclosed in a circular chamber containing a non-freezing solution of about 80 per cent. alcohol with distilled water. A device is provided to allow for expansion. The liquid is introduced to give a damping effect to the card and needles. The period of this compass is quick and "dead-beat," so that readings taken during, or immediately after, a turn are quite reliable. The compass case is mounted in a box fitted with springs in order to insulate it as far as possible from shocks and vibration. In order to correct for the deviation caused by the presence of iron near the compass, a device is fitted above the chamber consisting of tubes mounted at right angles to one another in the horizontal plane and shut off by a rotating sleeve. Small "wire" compensating magnets (marked half red and half blue for the N. and S. poles respectively) are placed in these tubes, according to the correction required, and locked therein by the rotating sleeve. It is not possible to achieve absolute correction in this manner. A compass similar to the one shown, but of the "slow-period" type, is also made. It has a period of about 48 seconds, and is particularly suitable for cloud flying.

description: This air-speed indicator differs from an ordinary air-speed indicator in having a connection to a suction tube only, which is set in a forward direction. The instrument comprises essentially a flat metal chamber, one end of which is formed by a corrugated metal diaphragm. The suction tube connects with the interior of the chamber, so that the pressure within the chamber is regulated by the air-speed. Any variation of pressure causes a movement of the diaphragm, to the centre of which is connected an axial arm, which by means of a quadrant transfers its motion to an axial shaft which is thereby caused to rotate. This shaft carries the pointer, which moves over a suitably graduated scale. The head of the instrument consists of a small annular tube, mounted in a larger one, which is slightly conical. In the inner surface of the annular tube is a series of small holes, so that the suction of the air passing the holes reduces the pressure in the annular space, which is also in connection with the metal chamber of the indicating instrument.

description: This instrument is designed primarily to enable the observer to calculate the compass course to be steered to make good a certain track on the ground when a cross-wind is blowing. It can also be used to ascertain the actual ground-speed in such a situation. The device is based on the principle of the resolution of velocities by means of the parallelogram of forces. A diagram by the object shows how this principle is applied. It will be seen that the two velocities with their directions form the sides of a parallelogram, the diagonal of which (A'/B') indicates the resultant velocity of the machine and its direction NE. while it is being steered NNE. The instrument is shown set for finding the compass course to be steered to make good a NE. track over the ground in a wind of 40 miles per hour from the W., the air-speed of the machine being 95 miles per hour. The arrow on the revolving disc is set to the course to be made good. One arm (A) is then set to the direction from which the wind is blowing, while the pointer (A') is set to its speed. The other arm (B) (with its pointer (B') set to the air-speed of the machine) is revolved till the pointer (B') is on the same line (parallel to the arrow) as the pointer (A') on the first arm (A). The second arm (B) now indicates the course to be steered, which is approximately NNE. By counting the squares from pointer to pointer it will be ascertained that the ground-speed is about 118 miles per hour.

description: This instrument is designed to calculate the amount of drift and the actual ground-speed for the purpose of aerial navigation. The angle of drift is easily ascertained by viewing an object through the celluloid and along the drift wire, and adjusting the latter until no deviation is apparent. The ground-speed is calculated by timing the aircraft over a distance on the ground which is known when viewed through the sights. The device consists of two rotating concentric rings and a middle ring, which constitutes the base plate, and is furnished with a securing bracket, which engages a fixed shoe on the aircraft. The inner ring is in the form of a dial, graduated in degrees and showing the cardinal points. The outer or sight-ring carries the forward and back sights ; it also carries a pivoted vertical arm, graduated in hundreds and thousands of feet, with a back sight adjustable for height. A drift wire is fitted along the centre of this arm. The inner ring or bearing plate is set by the compass on the aircraft ; the outer ring is then rotated till an object on the ground passes evenly along the drift wire, indicating that it agrees with the ground drift. The angle of ground drift, or actual track made good, can then be read off at the pointer, carried by the sights, against the bearing plate. In order to ascertain the ground speed it is necessary to adjust the movable back sight, thus altering the angle of view through the fore sight in proportion to the height of the machine above the ground. This gives a constant base line on the ground of half a statute mile. The time taken for any object to pass from the fore sight (viewed through the movable back sight) to the back sight is the time taken by the aircraft to cover this distance. A stop watch is employed to register the period.

description: This chart-board is designed to accommodate four or five aerial charts or maps. It has a protractor mounted on parallel links, which enable it to maintain the same angle when moved over the board. The course can be marked on the celluloid cover by means of a special pencil. This chart-board is 14 in. square, being designed for use on aircraft where space is limited. The charts are inserted by pulling out and turning down the brass clip on the right, and by slightly lifting the flap of the celluloid cover. The parallels are clamped by means of a screw, and when this has been done the protractor may be used over any portion of the board. In order to use the protractor, the large milled head is turned till the engraved arrow lies coincident with the magnetic meridian of the compass rose on the chart. The back screw is then eased, and the metal pointer is set to zero and reclamped ; it then indicates magnetic direction. To maintain any particular course, the protractor is turned till the pointer indicates the required angle ; it is then clamped by the small screw in the centre. The protractor will now record the desired angle wherever it is moved on the chart, and the course can be marked on the celluloid cover. In order to measure distance, the sides of the protractor are graduated in inches and tenths and numbered, in the direction of the arrow, from the departure point to the objective. The distance in inches and tenths is multiplied by the scale of the chart—in the case of a general chart by 10, which is the number of nautical miles to the inch. The protractor is equally available for maps where the scale is some fraction or multiple of an inch.

description: The object of this instrument is to warn the pilot when a water-cooled engine is in danger of overheating, and whether there is any loss, by boiling, in the water-cooling system. It consists of a small cylinder connected by air-tight tubing to a Bourdon pressure gauge. The cylinder is usually immersed in the radiator water, but it is sometimes fitted in the cooling jacket of the engine. It contains ether in both liquid and vaporous state. As the temperature of the water rises, the vapour pressure in the cylinder increases, and is registered by the Bourdon gauge. The scale is graduated to read up to 100° C., and as the boiling point of water decreases with height and reduced pressure, a red marking (indicating that at 10,000 ft. the boiling point is 93°) is provided to prevent any error on this account.

description: This early instrument, which automatically recorded the height reached, was modified for use in ballooning and in aeroplane work. The pen does not trace a line, as is usual in barographs, but dots every half minute. This frees the indication of the instrument from the drag due to the pen moving on the paper. With such an instrument a rough indication of the rate of climbing of an aeroplane can be made by counting the interspaces between the dots, and so getting the time of rising. A barograph of this type was used in the Military Aeroplane Competition, 1912.

description: This instrument is designed to inform the pilot of the height which he has attained. It measures atmospheric pressure, which decreases with altitude. The instrument consists of an aneroid barometer graduated to read in thousands of feet. The scale can be rotated by the milled head, and is usually adjusted to zero before the flight. This corrects for the barometric pressure of the day, and the altimeter then records the height above the starting point. If adjusted, before flight, to the known height of the starting point, it will record the altitude above sea-level. The accuracy of this type of instrument is affected by the varying temperature of the air at different altitudes and its "lag," or tardiness, in responding to sudden changes.

description: This instrument is constructed on the aneroid principle, and closely resembles altimeters of British design. An air-chamber is provided with a corrugated metal end, the centre of which is fitted with an axial bar. Variation of pressure effects a motion of the bar, which is communicated by means of a rod and quadrant to a spindle carrying the pointer, the motion of the spindle being a rotary one.

description: This was the first air-speed indicator for aircraft employing the principle of the rise of air pressure due to the velocity, above the pressure in a static box. It was originally calibrated on a motor-car, and afterwards used on the airships “Beta” and “Gamma,” and also on the first B.E. aeroplane. The head of the instrument consists of two long parallel tubes, one being a pressure tube and the second being connected with a small annular chamber provided with a number of small holes connecting with the atmosphere. The rush of air past this series of holes causes a suction in the tube in connection with this chamber. The indicator consists of two small chambers separated by a diaphragm, each chamber being in connection with one tube of the pressure head. Any difference in pressure in the two tubes is communicated to the diaphragm, which moves accordingly, and operates a spring-controlled arm connected thereto, which in turn actuates the pointer.
interpretation: This was the first air-speed indicator for aircraft employing the principle of the rise of air pressure due to the velocity, above the pressure in a static box.

description: The speed of aircraft in relation to the air is measured from the difference between the atmospheric pressure and that induced by the speed of flight. The instrument shown is of the Ogilvie type, and indicates this speed in miles per hour. It is connected with the pressure head adjacent. Two tubes from the pressure head are connected to the gauge and the pressure difference, which amounts to approximately 5 in. head of water at 100 miles per hour, deflects metal diaphragms in the instrument, the movement being communicated to the pointer by suitable gearing. The indicator only reads true air speed near the ground level, for at a height the reduction of air density causes the readings to be low. In order to correct for this, a computing ring is fitted, by means of which the true air speed may be calculated from the indicated speed. description: This instrument is used in conjunction with the air-speed gauge (see No. 94) to record the speed in relation to the air, and is connected to it by means of flexible tubing. It is usually mounted in an exposed position at the front of the aeroplane, as clear as possible from the propeller slip stream and the wing surfaces. This instrument consists of two tubes, known as the " static " and " pitot " tubes respectively. The static tube is closed at the end, and has small holes at the sides communicating with the outer air. Pressure inside this tube is not affected by its passage through the air. The pitot tube is open at the end and is arranged to face up stream. It records the atmospheric pressure plus the additional pressure produced by the speed of flight and the wind. The pressure difference between the two tubes is proportional to the density of the air and the square of the velocity of the machine.

description: This form of air-speed indicator, which was used considerably by the Germans during the war (1914-18), closely resembles the Ogilvie air-speed indicator. This instrument consists of a large metal chamber, divided into two portions by a partition carrying a rubber diaphragm. Increased pressure in one of these chambers, which is connected to the pressure tube of a pitot head, causes a motion of the rubber diaphragm, which is augmented by a corresponding decrease of pressure in the other chamber, which is in connection with the suction tube of the pitot head. The motion of the rubber diaphragm is transmitted through a quadrant to a spindle carrying the pointer, which is thus caused to travel along the graduated scale.

description: This instrument is principally used to warn the pilot when his machine is side-slipping. It is sometimes employed to indicate whether the aeroplane is keeping a steady, straight flight. It consists of a curved glass tube filled with a non-freezing solution; a bubble of air is imprisoned at the centre of the column of liquid. When mounted laterally in the aeroplane the bubble will, owing to centrifugal force, take up a central position during a turn if the machine is correctly " banked." If the aeroplane is under-banked, the bubble will move to the inside of the turn; in the case of an over-bank, to the outside. When mounted longitudinally, the spirit-level indicates any deviation from steady horizontal flight. An illuminating attachment for night flying is provided.

description: This apparatus is designed to supply oxygen to aviators when flying at altitudes where the air is greatly rarefied. The apparatus shown provides oxygen as soon as it is required, and in proportion to the reduction in atmospheric pressure. Compressed oxygen is contained in a light steel cylinder. It is fed through a Dryer regulator, which contains a diaphragm affected by atmospheric pressure. The amount of oxygen required by the user increases with height, and this is automatically provided for by a mechanism attached to the diaphragm, which allows more to pass as the atmospheric pressure decreases. A fan-flow meter is. provided to allow the user to gauge the amount of gas passing. The supply can be regulated to some degree, or shut off if desired, by means of the tap fitted between the regulator and the gauge. A length of flexible tubing connects the apparatus to a mask worn by the aviator.

description: This case contains a duplicate set of the instruments used in the Vickers-Vimy biplane on the first direct trans-Atlantic flight. The original instruments remain in position in the machine. 1. Pitot Tube.—The pitot tube or pressure head is fitted to the outer interplane strut of the machine and is connected to the instrument by means of rubber or aluminium tubing. The open end is connected to the pressure side of the diaphragm, whilst the closed end is connected to the opposite side of the diaphragm, its purpose being to keep the air at atmospheric pressure on this side of the diaphragm. 2. Density Meter.—This instrument is used to correct the ordinary air-speed indicator for the variation in altitude and temperature. The ordinary air-speed indicator under-registers on height, due to the diminished density of the atmosphere, and the density meter is calibrated in numbers, which, when multiplied by the M.P.H. shown on the ordinary air-speed indicator dial, gives the combined correction for variation of both altitude and temperature. 3. Pressure Gauge.—These pressure gauges are of the usual Bourdon tube type, and are made for any ranges from 5–160 lb. All gauges are fitted for over-load, to stand any extra pressure above which they are designed to register. 4. Radiator Thermometer.—This instrument indicates the temperature of the water in the engine cooling system, and depends for its action on the expansion of the ether in the bulb and tubing of the instrument. The expansion causes a pressure which is registered on the dial in degrees of temperature. The boiling point of water drops as the altitude increases, therefore a correction is necessary and can be made by referring to the boiling-point altimeter. 5. Longitudinal Clinometer.—This instrument is fitted with a tube containing greenish-yellow liquid, making it easy to read in semi-darkness. A certain quantity of the liquid is sealed in the tube and rises half-way up it, indicating zero degrees when the machine is flying level ; when the machine is climbing the liquid rises in the tube, and vice versâ when the machine descends. 6. Revolution Indicator.—This instrument is worked on the centrifugal principle, and indicates the engine revolutions in hundreds per minute. The connection to the engine is by means of a flexible drive, which is arranged by means of a gear box on the engine to run at quarter engine speed, the instrument itself being geared 4–1, enabling it to record the actual revolutions of the crank-shaft. 7. Scout Compass, Type 5/17.—This is the standard scout compass, and was used extensively during the war (1914–18). There is no float in this type of instrument, and the card is attached by a wire framework, carrying the magnetic system, to the pivot. The bearing is therefore extremely light, and the liquid has the maximum steadying effect on quick turns of the machine. 8. Air-Speed Indicator.—This instrument depends for its action on the movement of a specially treated silk diaphragm, which is unaffected by moisture or atmospheric conditions. The characteristic of this air-speed indicator lies in the fact that the diaphragm is not called upon to do any work, except that of a diaphragm ; that is to say, it is a mover only, the resistance to the movement being supplied by a highly tempered steel spring. 9. Altitude Recorder. - due to special construction, is practically without “lag.” It is fitted with a button to enable the instrument to be reset to zero to allow for variation in height of aerodromes above mean sea-level. The instrument is also engraved with a temperature scale showing the boiling point of water at various altitudes, enabling the pilot to correct his radiator thermometer when flying at various heights. 10. Wristlet Altimeter. - This instrument is practically the same as the standard model, and is used by the observer for bomb-dropping, &c. 11. “Time of Trip” Clock. - The principal advantage of this clock is the fact that it is fitted with a small subsidiary dial. The latter is quite independent of the ordinary dial showing the time of day, and can be stopped, started, and reset to zero, and records the actual number of hours’ flight made on any particular trip. 12. Lateral Clinometer. - This clinometer is the standard Air Ministry pattern, but with an improvement in the shape of a peculiar-coloured liquid, which shade has been found particularly easy to read between periods of twilight or semi-darkness. It is primarily designed for indicating lateral stability, and also to indicate when a correct “bank” is being made. 13. Compass, Pattern 253. - This instrument is now fitted with a prism, the bearing indicated on the card is thereby magnified several times, making it particularly easy to read from a distance.

description: HIGH ALTITUDE DRIFT, MARK. I.A. Lent by The Air Ministry. 1919. When a bomb is released from an aeroplane, it appears, to the observer on the ground, to describe a curve in the direction of the machine’s motion. A bomb sight is a device which enables a bomb to be so released that the target will be in the path of the curve described by it. It also indicates the right direction to steer when approaching the target and any lateral drift which may occur. The bomb sight shown can be used for bombing up or down wind at high altitudes, and is adjustable for bombs stowed vertically or horizontally. Inv. 1919-526.

description: This sight was designed by Major H. E. Wimperis for operating over sea. It enables bombing to be carried out in any direction relative to the wind, and can be used for navigational purposes. The instrument is based on the same principle as that of the high altitude drift sight, Mark Ia. The sight is provided with adjustment for height and for indicated air-speed. It is fitted with a pivoted wind bar, which can be set along any wind direction. For this purpose a compass is embodied in it, connected by gearing to the wind bar in such a manner that the wind arrow (D.B.), attached to the compass case, lies parallel to the wind bar and points down wind.

description: This German periscopic bomb sight is the most recent type of bomb-sighting instrument manufactured by C. P. Goerz, who concentrated on its production during the latter part of the war (1914-1918). It was used on the Gotha bombing aeroplanes. The height scale on the calculator (Höhe) is now adjusted from the altimeter, which brings the appropriate height scale (Gestoppte Zeit in Sekunden) into position. The index on this scale is set to the time previously determined, and the bombing angle is read on a second index on the angle scale (Vorhaltewinkel in Grad). A third scale gives the ground-speed should this require to be known. The method of attack is to set the angle scale to the bomb-dropping angle found in the above manner. This is facilitated by clamping the movable index to this angle as soon as it is known. The disc is rotated so as to bring the target well in view ahead, so securing a good run-up; when brought back the index falls into its notch and the correct setting is obtained. The sight is capable of rotation in azimuth, the movement serving to operate a variable electrical resistance situated at the base (not shown). When the machine is pointing at the target, a galvanometer before the pilot shows no deflection, the resistance being balanced so that no current passes. Unless the fore-and-aft line of the graticule points at the target the resistance balance is disturbed and the galvanometer is deflected. The steering can thus be modified to secure the correct approach. Inv.

description: Made by The Thornton-Pickard Manufacturing Co., Ltd., Altrincham. Received 1920. This was the first type of aerial camera used by the Royal Flying Corps early in 1915, and was designed by officers of the corps. Previously, ordinary press cameras had been employed. This camera consists of a brass-bound metal conical box with a recessed wooden front to which the lens is fixed, the extension of the camera body acting as a mechanical protection and as a shade for the lens, while at the back is the shutter frame into which the envelope holder for the Mackenzie-Wishart envelopes are fitted. The shutter is of the focal plane type, with adjustable slit, the distance being maintained by the usual cord and clip. An important feature of this shutter lies in the arrangement adopted to prevent the shutter being withdrawn until the blind is wound up. To effect this the shutter winding wheel is normally not in mesh. On pushing in the shutter of the envelope holder a peg jumps out of a cavity in the framework, and enters a depression in the shutter, which cannot now be withdrawn until the blind is fully wound. To effect this the winding wheel is pushed home and then engages the gear, the winding wheel is turned, and when the blind is fully wound up the peg holding the shutter of the plate holder falls out of the depression and the shutter can be withdrawn. The release of the shutter is made by means of a two-way thumb and finger lever conveniently placed at the right-hand side, the camera being held by means of adjustable straps or by brass handles. The camera is operated over the side of the machine, being held in the observer's hand. The camera is fitted with a cross-wire sight view-finder. The focal length of the lens is 8 in.

description: Received 1920. This camera, which is a development of the "A" type (see No. 106), was the first partially automatic plate-changing type, and was introduced early in 1916. In this type of camera the Mackenzie-Wishart holder has been removed and a frame is substituted. This frame is a repeating back with two openings, through one of which the exposure is made and through the other the exposed plate drops into a chamber. A magazine full of plates is placed in position over the shutter and a second empty magazine is fixed on the under side of the frame to receive the exposed plates. In this camera the process of plate-changing and setting the shutter is performed in one operation as in the later model "L" type (see No. 111).

description: This was the first type of metal aerial camera; it was in use during the early part of the war (1914–1918). description: The Williamson Kinematograph Co., Ltd. 1920 The general principles of this semi-automatic plate-changer type are similar to those now almost universally adopted for aerial plate photography. The process of changing the plate and setting the focal plane shutter is one operation, which may be accomplished either by hand, or automatically, by the action of wind on an air vane. This camera is provided with two magazines, each capable of holding 18 plates, the loaded one being placed in position in runners provided on top of the camera and the empty magazine beneath an extension. A hand lever on the side operates the plate changer and at the same time sets the focal plane shutter, while the knob, when pressed and released, exposes the plate. For automatic changing motive power is provided by a small air propeller, while the lever of the small auxiliary apparatus exposes the plate and releases the shutter, the time required to change the plate being about 10 seconds for an air speed of 50 miles per hour. The camera may also be operated at a distance by a single Bowden wire. The usual type of focal plane shutter is employed, with a sliding saddle to adjust the width of the opening. The blind is arranged as close as possible to the plate, being about ·1875 in. from it. A Ross 8·5-in. Xpress Lens is fitted. Inv. 1920-118. S.M. 1390. L.S.

description: This early form of gun camera, which was used for training purposes, was designed to be mounted on a Lewis gun, and was arranged so as to photograph the target. A graticule, divided into small squares, can be adjusted to the gun sights. The camera is adapted to take roll films 2·25 in. wide.

description: This apparatus was designed for testing small models of aircraft or various components by observing their behaviour in a current of air of known velocity. The example shown was made at the National Physical Laboratory, Teddington. The model to be tested is mounted on a delicate balancing apparatus in the tunnel, and a current of air is drawn through the tunnel by means of a fan. The velocity of the airstream may be regulated at will by the speed of the fan, and the tunnel is carefully designed to ensure that the airstream is free from eddies. Readings are made with great accuracy showing the effect of the model on the air-stream, and calculations are then made to apply to full-sized machines in flight, the information so obtained being used in the design of new aeroplanes. An anemometer has been placed in the channel to indicate to visitors the speed of the air current.

description: This apparatus is specially arranged to enable the streamline flow of water past variously shaped bodies to be examined. A large metal tank provided with a ball valve supplies a constant level of water, which is allowed to flow along two channels at a desired rate. A body is immersed in the water in one of these channels, and is securely held as the water flows past it. A small quantity of coloured liquid is introduced into the stream by means of a fine glass tube placed some distance in front of the object. By this means a fine coloured stream is carried along with the water, and by suitable adjustment can be arranged to indicate the path of the streamlines around the body.

description: These photographs, which illustrate the flow of water round obstacles and aerofoils, were taken when investigating the direction and velocity of flow in a fluid medium. The cloudy material is produced by coating the object with condensed milk, whilst the more clearly defined short lines in some of the photographs are produced by illuminated drops of oil. description: The eleven struts shown were tested for air resistance in order to find the best form of section for use on aeroplanes. The tests were carried out in a 4-ft. wind channel with an air speed of 28 ft. per second. Some of the struts are copies of those in use on actual flying machines, whilst others are deduced from experiments on dirigible balloon models. The relative merits are expressed in terms of extra weight carried, and the difference between good and bad struts in a biplane may be equivalent to the carrying of an extra passenger. The accompanying reproductions of photographs taken at the National Physical Laboratory illustrate the flow of water round some of the struts. Short portions of the struts were cut off and fixed in a small water channel with glass sides. The flow of water round the struts was then indicated by the introduction of colouring matter into the stream. In the case of struts with blunt tails, such as are found in "De Havilland" (direct and reversed), "Blériot," and "Baby" (reversed), a mass of dead water, i.e., of a region of low pressure, and therefore of high resistance, is indicated behind the strut. The table exhibited near by gives the results of the tests.

description: These small ebonite models were used for finding the best shape of envelope for dirigible balloons. The tests were made in water at a speed of 1.78 ft. per second. The two larger models are similar to one of the small ones (marked A), and were tested in the William Froude national tank at speeds varying from 2 to 20 ft. per second. Tests were also made in air with the medium-sized model. These model tests give the law of variation of resistance with size and speed. Experiments have shown that, for airship envelopes, a law of a resistance proportional to (speed) 1.86 holds for practical purposes, and that the co-efficients obtained from tests on models indicate fairly closely those which must be used for full-sized machines. The accompanying diagram and table show how the resistance varies with the shape of the tail.

description: These strainers, which are of the type used in aeroplane construction, were tested at East London College in order to provide data for the design of strainers of such dimensions that the strength of the gun-metal body portion should be equal to the strength of the steel-screwed portion at the bottom of the thread. The strainers were arranged with pins placed through the eyes, and a load was gradually put on to these pins until the specimen broke. All the specimens, with one exception, broke in the screwed-steel portion at the break, proving that this portion is the weakest part of the turnbuckle. Several of the turnbuckles were next turned down until the gun-metal portion was obviously weaker than the steel portion. These specimens were again tested to destruction, and from these tests and the single specimen which broke in the gun-metal portion during the first test, the average tensile strength of the gun-metal was found to be 20 tons per sq. in. The correct dimensions of the parts for equal strength everywhere were then calculated.

description: In order to measure the velocity of the air in a wind channel, a Pitot tube is usually employed. It consists of two tubes placed in the air current so that the open end of one of them faces the stream and determines the dynamic pressure, while the other measures the pressure of the free air in the neighbourhood, i.e., the static pressure. The two tubes are connected to a water gauge, and the difference between the two pressures thus obtained is a direct measure of the velocity of the air. The velocity nozzle shown was made at the Royal Aircraft Factory, is known as a “R.A.F. tube,” and was designed to secure magnified readings on the manometer, which constitutes an air-speed meter. The static pressure tube is, in this example, enclosed by a cone that forms a “dead water” region, and in which there is a negative pressure.

description: The model represents a hot-air balloon of the type designed, in 1783, by the brothers J. E. and Joseph M. Montgolfier, to whom is credited, in consequence, the invention of the aerostatic airship. On the 5th June of that year, at Annonay, near Lyons, they made their first public exhibition with a paper balloon about 35 ft. diameter, which was filled with hot air by means of a fire placed below it. The balloon, which weighed 300 lb., rose to a height of 6,000 ft. Subsequently, on the 19th October, 1783, M. Pilâtre de Rozier and the Marquis d'Arlandes ascended at Paris in a Montgolfier balloon represented by the model. It was of oval shape, made of canvas, with the outside painted and decorated with the signs of the zodiac. The aperture or lower part of the balloon had a wicker gallery of 16 ft. internal diameter. A brazier was supported in the centre of the gallery by chains connected with the sides of the balloon. The fire was maintained as required during the ascent by using straw, wood, etc., as fuel.

description: The drawing represents approximately the external features of a German dirigible military balloon of the Zeppelin type. The special feature of the construction consists of an aluminium framework which, combined with a rigid keel, preserves the shape of the envelope; hence it is known as the rigid type. The first balloon of this type was built in 1898 by Graf von Zeppelin, and underwent trials in 1900 at Friedrichshafen, on Lake Constance. Subsequent modifications have been in the direction chiefly of greater size and increased motive power. The first flight of a Zeppelin military airship took place in March, 1909. In the first balloon the outer framework of aluminium, which was strongly braced, was covered with linen and silk and enclosed an inner shell, the annular space between them being filled with air. This air acted as an insulator and prevented excessive changes of temperature in the gas contained in the inner shell. The latter was divided into 17 gas-tight compartments, each of which contained a balloon. The motive power was obtained by two motors developing 16 h.p. at 700 revolutions per minute. There were four propellers of 3.75 ft. diameter, geared to run at 1,100 revolutions per minute.

description: The modern parachute is a life-saving apparatus enabling a safe descent to be made from an airship or aeroplane, even in a high wind. The parachute shown is one of the type manufactured by Messrs. C. G. Spencer & Sons for the Royal Air Force, and used with great success by kite balloon observers during the war (1914–18). The harness fitted is of the “Guardian Angel ” (Calthrop) type. The supporting surface of this parachute is made of fine quality black silk, formed in the section of a sphere. This section has a diameter, when measured on the ground, of 28 ft., but it is contracted to 21 ft. when carrying a load in the air. There is a vent hole at the apex, having a diameter of about eight inches. Compressed air escapes through this hole in a vertical stream, and acts as a universal rudder. Beneath the parachute the air is compressed in the form of an inverted cone, the pressure increasing upwards to the parachute body. The maximum air pressure is within the body and as it escapes over the edge of the periphery. The rigging consists of 48 lines, which run from the fabric a distance of about 5 ft. From this point 24 lines are employed; they run direct to a wooden ring, 14 in. diameter. The harness is connected to this ring by a length of rope and is easily removable. The “Guardian Angel” harness, patented in 1914 by Mr. E. R. Calthrop, consists of two oval aluminium arm-pieces connected to a web belt. The parachute is attached directly to these arm-pieces and to the belt. The parachutist’s body is supported by the arm-pieces, the belt, and by a strap which passes between the legs. A quick re’ease mechanism is fitted to guard against the danger of being dragged along the ground after alighting. When the lever is moved to the vertical the three parts of the fastening are unlocked and the harness may be instantly removed. In the locked position the lever is kept stationary by means of the leather slide. When the parachute is withdrawn from the case it opens in two to three seconds, the momentum is absorbed, and the parachutist adopts the average rate of fall, which is, approximately, 16 ft. per second, or 10.9 miles per hour. All this takes place in a vertical fall of about 100 ft. There is practically no free fall, and no shock is experienced. The impact on landing is equivalent to that of a jump from a height of four feet.

description: This model represents a free balloon of the type used prior to the war (1914–18) for observation and sporting purposes. The actual balloon had a diameter of 50 ft., and consisted of an envelope of varnished fabric, fitted with an interior bag of goldbeaters’ skin. The envelope of this balloon is made of cotton fabric, which has been doped and varnished in order to strengthen it and to render it impervious to moisture. The process increased the strength of the fabric by 20 to 25 per cent. The interior bag, which contains the lifting agent, is made of three-ply gold-beaters’ skin and is fitted with the valve necessary for descent; this valve is controlled from the car. The lifting agent usually employed was hydrogen. A wicker car, attached to the envelope by netting, provides accommodation for the passengers and carries the ballast necessary in order properly to control the ascent.

description: Model constructed in the Museum Workshops, from data supplied by the Air Ministry. Model constructed in the Museum Workshops / Messrrs. Beardmore (original builder). This rigid airship was built by Messrs. Beardmore for H.M. Government during the latter part of the war (1914–1918). It was the first lighter-than-air craft to achieve a direct Trans-Atlantic flight, the journey being made from East Fortune, Scotland, to Mineola, Long Island, U.S.A. The airship was wrecked in 1921 as the result of an accident following a cruise over the North Sea. H.M. Airships R.33 and R.34 represented a type based on the design of the German super-Zeppelin L.33, launched in 1916. The two British vessels were nearly identical in design and were constructed simultaneously. It was found on completion that R.34 was in some respects superior and having an increased lift was capable of carrying a greater quantity of fuel; for this reason she was selected to make a Transatlantic crossing. The rigid structure, or framework, in this airship consists of a number of polygons built up of individual duralumin girders spaced ten metres apart longitudinally and joined from corner to corner by other lattice girders, the whole being braced with steel wire. The gasbags, or balloonets, nineteen in number, are enclosed between these transverse polygonal frames and are made of fine cotton proofed with a layer of rubber to which is attached a layer of gold-beater’s skin. Four cars are suspended from the hull structure. The forward or control, car contains the instruments for navigation, the various controls, the apparatus for wireless telegraphy and telephony, and one engine. The wing cars, which are slung amidships, each contain an engine and provide accommodation for the mechanics. The large car aft contains an auxiliary control position and two engines. Enclosed at the bottom of the structure is a corridor of triangular section which runs the full length of the ship and affords access to all parts including the cars and provides accommodation for the crew, the petrol tanks and the water ballast.

description: This two-seater tractor biplane was designed and built at the Royal Aircraft Factory, South Farnborough, in 1916, and was subsequently produced by the Daimler Co., Ltd. It was known as the Reconnaissance Experimental No 8, having been constructed especially for reconnoitring purposes. The machine was used considerably for corps reconnaissance and observation during the latter part of the war (1914–1918). The R.E.8 was evolved in part from an earlier biplane, the B.E.2e, and contained all the essential features of the Royal Aircraft Factory design. It was fitted with a 150 horse-power engine known as the R.A.F. 4a. (See Inv. No. 1920–38.) The pilot’s cockpit was situated slightly behind the centre section ; the observer occupied a position in rear and was provided with a machine gun on a ring mounting. There was a pronounced stagger between the planes, and the upper plane had a greater span. The undercarriage was of typical Vee type. A four-bladed tractor air-screw was fitted. The biplane was still in use at the end of the war (1914–1918) for artillery observation and night bombing. The principal data are : Span of top plane, 42·7 ft. ; overall length, 27·8 ft. ; height, 10·8 ft. ; total supporting surface, 388 sq. ft. ; weight, 1,803 lbs. ; weight fully loaded, 2,869 lbs. ; loading, 7·4 lbs. per sq. ft. description: This single-seater tractor biplane (The British Experimental No. 12) was designed and manufactured at the Royal Aircraft Factory, South Farnborough, in 1916–1917, for general military purposes. The machine has all the essential features of the Royal Aircraft Factory design and is fitted with a 150 horse-power R.A.F. 4a engine. The pilot’s cockpit is situated slightly in rear of the main planes, which are cut away in order to provide a clear view. No armament is shown in the model, but various devices for attack were fitted to the biplane according to the purpose for which it was intended. description: This receiver was designed for use by H.M. aerial forces during the war (1914–1918). The instrument is intended for the reception of both spark and continuous wave signals and may be used in aircraft either for wireless telegraphy or telephony. For the principle on which this instrument is based see wireless apparatus, collection of electrical engineering. The receiver is a combined tuner, detector and amplifier. It is capable of receiving spark signals on the wave length ranges of 150–350 metres and 500–700 metres. In addition it can receive both spark and continuous wave signals on the range of 1,000–2,500 metres. Three hard vacuum valves of the French pattern are employed. The first acts as a detector and high-frequency amplifier, while the second and third amplify audio-frequencies only. A filament rheostat is situated in the middle of the terminal panel. It consists of a helix of manganin wire of 1·2 ohms resistance. A detector valve grid condenser of 1·6 jars capacity, with mica dielectric, is connected to the grid of the first valve and is shunted by a carbon rod resistance. The carbon rod resistance is of the Remco type and of approximately 2 megohms. The multiple-segment wave length switch has three positions, one for each of the three ranges of wave-length. It makes all the necessary connections in each case, with the exception of the parallel condenser which has a separate adjust-ment. The timing variometer has inside and outside coils wound with 7/36 S.W.G. copper wire. The inductance of each coil when alone is approximately 290 microhms; when connected in series as a variometer the range is from 140 to 1,060 microhms. The variometer is graduated in degrees only, calibration cards being supplied for the various aerial capacities. The terminals of the instrument are arranged so that it may be used conveniently on a closed aerial coil for direction finding. The parallel condensers are four in number. They have copper foil conductors and mica dielectric clamped together between ebonite plates. Their capacities are marked above the switch. Two telephone jacks are fitted, one being in the anode circuit of the first valve and the other in the anode circuit of the third valve. The batteries required are one of 6 volts and one of 100 volts. They are connected to the plug sockets which are marked appropriately.

description: This tapping key is intended for use on aircraft in conjunction with the transmitter, Type 52 Modified (see No. 114a), for the sending of signals. The instrument is mounted on an ebonite base and enclosed in an aluminium box. It has a centrally pivoted moving part to which the operating handle is attached. Heavy platinum points are fitted for making and breaking the circuit. Two adjustments are provided for the purpose of varying the movement of the key. One consists of a screw with a milled head which projects through the aluminium casing and can be conveniently operated while in the air. The leads from the transmitter are brought up through holes in the ebonite base plate and are secured to terminals mounted thereon.
interpretation: This tapping key is intended for use on aircraft for the sending of signals.
